A list of 101 children was to be shared with the ACLU within the following day.<ref name="nbc-2018-07-06"/> A status conference was scheduled for the morning of July 9 concerning which cases would merit a delay.<ref name="judge-rejects-blanket-delay-2018-07-06"/><ref name="nbc-2018-07-06"/> On July 6, a government lawyer provided the status of 102 children under 5 in custody to Federal Judge Dana Sabraw, and stated that numbers are approximate and "in flux".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/07/06/trump-administration-asks-court-more-time-family-reunification-deadlin/|title=Some migrant children under 5 unlikely to be reunited with their parents by Tuesday deadline|last1=Parker|first1=Claire|date=July 6, 2018|work=The Texas Tribune|last2=Platoff|first2=Emma |accessdate=July 7, 2018}}</ref>
In September 2018 it was reported that 12,800 children were being held in federal custody, and that federal shelters housing migrant children were filled to around 90% since May 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/feds-holding-12800-migrant-children-in-detention-centers-report-says/|title=Feds holding 12,800 migrant children in detention centers, report says|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en}}</ref>
==== Reunification ==== On July 9, the government stated that the number of parents deported alone and the number of parents released to the United States alone were each nine, rather than 19. As of that date, two parents of children younger than five had been reunited. The government said that more than fifty parents would be reunited with their small children on July 10, and that they would be released from ICE custody into the United States after being reunited.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/immigration/2018/07/09/3a253b22-838a-11e8-8553-a3ce89036c78_story.html|title=More than 50 separated children to be reunited with parents Tuesday|last1=Sacchetti|first1=Maria|date=July 9, 2018|work=The Washington Post |last2=Perry|first2=Tony |accessdate=July 10, 2018}}</ref> DoJ lawyer Sarah Fabian stated that of the 102 children, 75 were eligible for release and 27 could not be immediately be reunited for various reasons.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Maria Sacchetti, Arelis R. Hernández and Marissa J. Lang|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/immigration/2018/07/10/73fd24c0-8436-11e8-8553-a3ce89036c78_story.html|title=Some children are returned to parents, but judge tells Trump officials to move faster|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=July 10, 2018|access-date=July 11, 2018}}</ref>
An HHS official reported that of the 102 children, 38 had been returned to their families by Tuesday evening, and that more reunions were to continue "throughout the night".<ref>{{Cite news|author=Holly Yan, Darran Simon|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/07/10/politics/family-reunifications-july-10-deadline/index.html|title='A chaotic day': Officials and nonprofits try to reunite toddlers separated from parents|publisher=CNN|date=July 11, 2018|access-date=July 11, 2018}}</ref> The administration gave reasons why the remaining 64 children were not united by the deadline. According to the administration, in one case, parent and child may both be U.S. citizens.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Michelle Mark|url=https://www.businessinsider.de/trump-administration-family-separation-us-citizen-child-separated-2018-7|title=The Trump administration might have separated a child and parent who are both US citizens|publisher=Business Insider|date=July 11, 2018|access-date=July 11, 2018}}</ref>
On July 23, the administration stated that 879 parents had been reunited with their children, another 538 have been cleared for reunification, further 463 parents had cases that were still under review, and further 454 were either considered not eligible or were not yet known to be eligible for reunification with their children. More than 450 parents may have already been deported without their children.<ref>{{cite news |author=John Bacon|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/07/24/immigration-parents-may-have-been-deported-without-kids/824904002/|title=463 parents may have been deported without kids|newspaper=USA Today|date=July 24, 2018|access-date=July 24, 2018}}</ref> On July 26, 1,637 children were deemed eligible for reunification and 711 were deemed not eligible. So far, 1,442 had been reunited. Those deemed not eligible included 431 whose parents may have been deported and 120 with parents who waived reunification.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Daniel Gonzalez, Arizona Republic|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/07/26/feds-race-against-clock-reunify-immigrant-families-caught-border/844107002/|title=Feds race to reunify immigrant families separated at border to meet court-imposed deadline|newspaper=USA Today|date=July 27, 2018|access-date=July 27, 2018}}</ref>
=== Fiscal costs and diversion of resources === The costs of separating migrant children from their parents and keeping them in "tent cities" are higher than keeping them with their parents in detention centers.<ref name=Ainsley>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/immigration-border-crisis/trump-admin-s-tent-cities-cost-more-keeping-migrant-kids-n884871 |title=Tent cities cost millions more than keeping migrant kids with parents |publisher=NBC News |first=Julia |last=Ainsley |date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> It costs $775 per person per night to house the children when they are separated but $256 per person per night when they are held in permanent HHS facilities and $298 per person per night to keep the children with their parents in ICE detention centers.<ref name=Ainsley />
To handle the large amount of immigration charges brought by the Trump administration, federal prosecutors had to divert resources from other crime cases.<ref name=Heath>{{Cite news |url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/06/22/zero-tolerance-immigration-crackdown-diverting-resources-drug-cases/727532002/ |title=DOJ: Trump's immigration crackdown 'diverting' resources from drug cases |work=[[USA Today]] |first=Brad |last=Heath |access-date=June 23, 2018}}</ref> The head of the Justice Department's major crimes unit in [[San Diego]] diverted staff from drug smuggling cases.<ref name=Heath/> Drug smuggling cases were also increasingly pursued in state courts rather than federal courts, as federal prosecutor were increasingly preoccupied with pursuing charges against illegal border crossings.<ref name=Heath /> In October 2018, ''USA Today'' reported that federal drug-trafficking prosecutions on the Southern border plummeted, as prosecutorial resources were diverted to the family separation policy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/investigations/2018/10/10/border-drug-trafficking-prosecutions-plunged-zero-tolerance/1521128002/|title=As feds focused on detaining kids, border drug prosecutions plummeted|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en}}</ref>
It was reported in June 2018, that the Trump administration plans to pay a Texas Non-Profit [[Southwest Key Programs Inc,]] more than $458 million in the fiscal year of 2018 to care for immigrant children detained crossing the US border illegally.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/5316722/nonprofit-paid-458-million-trump-administration-detain-migrant-children-family-separation/|title=Nonprofit to Be Paid $458 Million to Detain Migrant Children|publisher=Time|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
In July 2018, it was reported that HHS had diverted at least $40 million from its health programs to care for and reunify migrant children, and that the HHS was preparing to shift more than $200 million from other HHS accounts.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/18/trump-migrants-health-programs-692955|title=Trump's migrant fiasco diverts millions from health programs|work=Politico|access-date=July 18, 2018}}</ref> In September 2018, it was reported that the Trump administration planned to shift more than $260 million from HHS programs, including those on cancer research and HIV/AIDS research, to cover the costs associated with detaining children and delaying releasing them to adults.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/09/20/politics/hhs-shifting-money-cancer-aids-immigrant-children/index.html|title=Trump admin moves $260M from cancer research, HIV/AIDS programs to cover custody of immigrant children costs|last=CNN|first=Tal Kopan,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-09-29}}</ref>
=== ProPublica audio tape === On June 18, 2018, as reporters waited for a briefing by the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security [[Kirstjen Nielsen]], [[ProPublica]] posted a recording of crying children begging for their parents just after being separated from them, which the reporters listened to as they waited for her to speak. Nielsen arrived and spoke, blaming Congress for the administration's policy of separating parents from their children and saying that there would be no change in policy until Congress rewrote the nation's immigration laws. At one point during the briefing, [[New York (magazine)|''New York'' magazine]] reporter Olivia Nuzzi played the tape. Nielsen refused to answer any questions about the material in the tape, such as "How is this not child abuse?"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Engelberg |first1=Stephen |title=DHS Chief is Confronted With ProPublica Tape of Wailing Children Separated from Parents |url=https://www.propublica.org/article/kirstjen-nielsen-homeland-security-crying-children-white-house-press-briefing |publisher=ProPublica |accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref>
Most of the tape consists of children crying and wailing for their parents, but a six-year-old girl is heard to repeatedly beg that her aunt be called, who she is certain will come and pick her up. ProPublica was able to contact the aunt, however the aunt was unable to assist for fear that her own petition of asylum would be put in jeopardy due to the recent Trump Administration decision to discontinue asylum protections for victims of gang and domestic violence. The aunt said that she was able to keep in touch with her niece by phone and that she had talked to her sister; however, her sister had not yet been allowed to speak with her child. The aunt said that the authorities had told the child that her mother may be deported without her.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/children-separated-from-parents-border-patrol-cbp-trump-immigration-policy|title=Listen to Children Who've Just Been Separated From Their Parents at the Border — ProPublica|date=June 18, 2018|publisher=ProPublica|others=Ginger Thompson|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref>
Commenting on President Trump's executive order and how it was related to the tape of the children crying, Republican commentator [[Leslie Sanchez]] commented on [[Face the Nation]], "And a lot of Republicans I talked to, even bundlers, people that put big amounts of money together, said, when they heard the cries of the children, without visual, being separated, that was the moment where America knew this was too far. And that's when the president retreated."<ref>{{cite news |title=Full transcript: "Face the Nation" for June 24, 2018 |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/full-transcript-face-the-nation-for-june-24-2018/ |work=Face the Nation |accessdate=June 25, 2018}}</ref>
===Allegations of forced medication and mistreatment===
There are concerns that the facilities that children were held in may have in the past been associated with the forcible drugging of children. The ''[[Texas Tribune]]'' reported that detained children who had previously been held at the Shiloh Treatment Center said they had been forcibly treated with [[antipsychotic drugs]] by the facility personnel, based on legal filings from a class action lawsuit. According to the filings, the drugs made the children listless, dizzy and incapacitated, and in some cases unable to walk. According to a mother, after receiving the drug, her child repeatedly fell, hitting her head and eventually ending up in a wheel chair. Another child stated that she tried to open a window, at which point one of the supervisors hurled her against a door, choked her until she fainted and had a doctor forcibly administer an injection while she was being held down by two guards. A [[Forensic psychiatry|forensic psychiatrist]] consulted by the ''Tribune'' compared the practice to what "[[Political abuse of psychiatry in the Soviet Union|the old Soviet Union used to do]]".<ref name="auto3">{{cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/06/20/immigrant-children-forcibly-injected-drugs-lawsuit-claims/|title=Immigrant children forcibly injected with drugs at Texas shelter, lawsuit claims|date=June 20, 2018|publisher=The Texas Tribune}}</ref><ref name="auto4">{{cite news |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/usworld/immigrant-children-forcibly-injected-with-psychiatric-drugs-lawsuit-claims/article_79e5fe52-8046-5e9c-82f6-e851765b3f3a.html|title=Immigrant children forcibly injected with psychiatric drugs, lawsuit claims|first1=Matt|last1=Smith|first2=Aura|last2=Bogado|newspaper=Tulsa World}}</ref><ref name="pri.org">{{cite news|url=https://www.pri.org/stories/2018-06-20/migrant-children-coming-us-are-being-sent-shelters-histories-child-abuse|title=Migrant children coming to the US are being sent to shelters with histories of child abuse allegations|publisher=PRI }}</ref><ref name="auto6">{{cite news |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/ny-news-drugging-immigrant-children-20180620-story.html|title=Government-funded treatment center forcibly injected immigrant kids with drugs: legal filings|first=Megan|last=Cerullo|newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune}}</ref><ref name="auto7">{{cite news |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/06/report-finds-long-history-of-abuse-in-child-migrant-shelters.html|title=Report: Nearly Half of Funding for Child Migrant Care Went to Shelters With Histories of Abuse|first=Molly|last=Olmstead|publisher=Slate}}</ref>
The treatment center is one of the companies that have been investigated on charges of mistreating children, although the federal government continues to employ the private agency which runs it as a federal contractor.<ref name="auto3"/><ref name="auto4"/><ref name="pri.org"/><ref name="auto6"/><ref name="auto7"/>
On July 30, a federal judge ruled that government officials have been in violation of state child welfare laws when giving psychotropic drugs to migrant children without first seeking the consent of their parents or guardians. According to the ruling given by Judge [[Dolly Gee]], staff members have admitted to signing off on medications in lieu of a parent, relative, or guardian. The judge also ordered that the government must move all children from the facility except for those deemed by a licensed professional to pose a “risk of harm” to themselves or others.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Schmidt |first1=Samantha |title=Trump administration must stop giving psychotropic drugs to migrant children without consent, judge rules |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/07/31/trump-administration-must-seek-consent-before-giving-drugs-to-migrant-children-judge-rules/ |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=July 31, 2018}}</ref>
=== Deterrence === Government data of arrests by border agents suggest that the family separation policy did little to deter migrants from crossing the US border illegally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/border-arrest-data-suggest-trumps-push-to-split-migrant-families-had-little-deterrent-effect/2018/08/08/0f452f0e-9a85-11e8-b55e-5002300ef004_story.html|title=Border arrest data suggest Trump’s push to split migrant families had little deterrent effect|last=|first=|date=|website=Washington Post|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref>
==Legal proceedings== ===ACLU challenge and nationwide injunction=== The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] filed an class-action lawsuit against the federal government on behalf of two mothers (one from Brazil, one from [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]) who had been separated from their children, seeking a halt to the policy. On June 25, the ACLU requested an injunction halting the policy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-otc-flores/aclu-class-counsel-for-migrant-kids-dispute-doj-on-crucial-flores-detention-issue-idUSKBN1JL2U3|title=ACLU, class counsel for migrant kids dispute DOJ on crucial Flores detention issue|last=Frankel|first=Alison|publisher=Reuters|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://files.acrobat.com/a/preview/2c196b47-ccbd-4802-b4a2-ce4eedcca9be|title=Plaintiffs' Supplemental Memorandum in Support of Classwide Preliminary Injunction|publisher=American Civil Liberties Union Immigrant Rights Project |date=June 25, 2018|format=PDF|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> On June 26, 2018, U.S. District Judge [[Dana Sabraw]] of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] issued a nationwide [[preliminary injunction]] against the family-separation policy.<ref name="FedJudgeInjunction"/><ref name="PrelimInjunctionText"/>
In his opinion, Sabraw wrote: "The facts set forth before the court portray reactive governance — responses to address a chaotic circumstance of the government's own making. They belie measured and ordered governance, which is central to the concept of due process enshrined in our [[United States Constitution|Constitution]]. This is particularly so in the treatment of migrants, many of whom are asylum seekers and small children."<ref name="FedJudgeInjunction" /><ref name="PrelimInjunctionText" /> Judge Sabraw wrote that the federal government "readily keeps track of personal property of detainees in criminal and immigration proceedings", yet "has no system in place to keep track of, provide effective communication with, and promptly produce alien children".<ref name=Gerstein /> The injunction barred the U.S. government from separating parents and children at the border unless the adults presented a danger to children, and required the government to reunite separated families within 30 days, to reunite children under five years of age with parents within 14 days, and to permit all separated minors to speak with their parents within ten days.<ref name="FedJudgeInjunction" /><ref name="PrelimInjunctionText" />
==== Status hearing ==== Judge Sabraw set a status hearing for July 6.<ref>{{cite news|author=Laura Jarrett|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/26/politics/federal-court-order-family-separations/index.html|title=Federal judge orders reunification of parents and children, end to most family separations at border|publisher=CNN|date=June 27, 2018|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> On July 6, the Trump administration asked for more time to reunite migrant families separated, highlighting the challenge of confirming familial relationship between parents and children, with parents of 19 of 101 detained children under the age of 5 already deported according to a [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] lawyer.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/06/us/migrant-children-court-families.html|title=Trump Administration Says It Needs More Time to Reunite Migrant Families|access-date=July 7, 2018}}</ref> The Judge set another deadline of Tuesday (July 10) for reunification, and gave the government until Saturday evening to create a list of all 101 youngest children along with an explanation of proposed difficulties. With the list the Judge believed that the two sides would be able to have "... an intelligent conversation Monday (July 9) morning about which child can be reunited July 10, which can not - and then the court can determine whether it makes sense to relax the deadline".<ref name=":5" />
==== Second ACLU lawsuit ====
Charging the Trump Administration with initiating new government screening policies designed to bar immigrants from entering the country by preventing them from getting a fair hearing, on August 7, 2018, the ACLU filed a lawsuit which focuses on migrants who have been placed in fast-track deportation proceedings known as “expedited removal.” The lawsuit was filed on behalf of 12 migrants who failed their “credible fear” interviews, one of the first steps for asylum seekers in the fast-track removal process.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sacchetti |first1=Maria |title=ACLU files suit challenging Trump administration’s new asylum rules |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/immigration/aclu-files-suit-challenging-trump-administrations-new-asylum-rules/2018/08/07/08155ff0-99a5-11e8-b60b-1c897f17e185_story.html?utm_term=.53ec3d8d97e0 |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=August 10, 2018}}</ref>
===Challenge by 17 states=== On June 26, a separate legal challenge to the family separation was brought by 17 states (California, Delaware, Iowa, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont, Virginia and Washington) against the Trump administration.<ref name="FedJudgeInjunction"/> The suit was filed in the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Washington|U.S. District Court in Seattle]]. The plaintiff states, all of whom have Democratic [[state attorneys general]], challenge the forcible separation of families as a "cruel and unlawful" violation of the constitution's [[Due Process Clause|Due Process]] and [[Equal Protection Clause]].<ref>Gene Johnson, [http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-states-lawsuit-family-separations-20180626-story.html 17 states sue to force Trump administration to reunite migrant families separated at border], Associated Press (June 26, 2018).</ref><ref name="FedJudgeInjunction"/> [[Washington Attorney General]] [[Bob Ferguson (politician)|Bob Ferguson]] is leading the suit. California Attorney General [[Xavier Becerra]], who represents California, called Trump's executive order putting a halt to the policy as an "empty and meaningless order that claims to take back policies that he [Trump] put in place himself as a political stunt".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article213608904.html|title=California to sue Trump administration over family separation policy|last=Hart|first=Angela|date=June 21, 2018|work=The Sacramento Bee|access-date=June 24, 2018}}</ref>
In a new motion filed on July 2, the group asked for immediate information and access to those that are being detained. The motion included more than 900 pages of declarations from family members as well as others that have been involved in the separation of the families. On July 5, [[PBS Newshour]] reported on 12 of the 99 declarations that they believe "offer a window into what's has been happening under the family separation policy". PBS included information from the declaration of one mother who wrote that her 1-year-old son was taken from her at a legal point of entry in November. She said that when they were reunited after three months he cried continually and when she removed his clothing she found him to be dirty and infected with lice. Others spoke of multiple detainees, including young children, held in very small rooms or cages, sometimes "freezing" cold, and without adequate bathroom facilities. Several others wrote of a lack of food, including food for children. One woman wrote that she was kept in a cell with nearly 50 other mothers and they were told "that they could not eat because they were asking about their children."<ref>{{cite news |title='My son is not the same': New testimony paints bleak picture of family separation |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/my-son-is-not-the-same-new-testimony-paints-bleak-picture-of-family-separation |work=PBS News Hour |accessdate=July 6, 2018}}</ref>
===''Flores'' filings === On June 21, 2018, the Department of Justice (DoJ) asked U.S. District Court Judge [[Dolly M. Gee|Dolly Gee]] to alter her 2015 ruling in ''[[Reno v. Flores]]'' on the conditions of family detention by the Department of Homeland Security. The government seeks to end a 20-day limit on family detention and to end the requirement that children be held in day care centers that are state-licensed.<ref name=Gerstein>[https://www.politico.com/f/?id=00000164-23ef-d8b4-aff7-e7efaec70000 Filing of June 21, 2018], referenced by: {{Cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/21/trump-administration-flores-agreement-change-662962 |title=Trump administration asks court to alter decree to OK family detention|work=Politico |first=Josh |last=Gerstein |access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> The DoJ filing claims that limits on detention must be ended due to "a destabilizing migratory crisis".<ref name=Gerstein/> Attorney Peter Schey, who represents the child plaintiffs in Flores, vowed to oppose the filing<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.chron.com/news/texas/article/The-Latest-Mayors-accuse-Trump-of-humanitarian-13014298.php|title=APNewsBreak: About 500 kids reunited with families since May|work=Houston Chronicle|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> He filed an opposition on the grounds of there having been no significant change in circumstances warranting such a revision of the ruling.<ref>[https://www.politico.com/f/?id=00000164-509b-d1bc-afef-5c9b2ea40001 Filing, Attorney Peter Schey], referenced by {{cite news |author=Josh Gerstein|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/29/flores-agreement-immigrant-families-separated-689494|title=Feds: Decades-old court decree allows family immigration detention|newspaper=Politico |date=June 29, 2018|accessdate=July 1, 2018}}</ref> On June 29, the DoJ filed a statement that in future the Government will ″detain families together during the pendency of immigration proceedings when they are apprehended at or between ports of entry″ in place of separating them.<ref>[https://www.justice.gov/opa/case-document/file/1077076/download Filing of June 29, 2018], referenced by: {{Cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/6/30/17520820/families-together-detention-separate-camp-military|title=It's official: The Trump administration has replaced family separation with indefinite family detention|work=Vox|date=June 30, 2018 |first=Dara |last=Lind |access-date=July 2, 2018}}</ref>
On July 9, Judge Gee denied the government's request to hold families together indefinitely in ICE facilities, and its request to exempt detention facilities from state licensing requirements for that purpose.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/09/judge-rejects-trump-request-flores-immigrant-children-704019|title=Judge rejects Trump request to alter agreement on release of immigrant kids|last=Gerstein|first=Josh|date=July 9, 2018|work=Politico|accessdate=July 10, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/07/10/federal-judge-denies-trump-administrations-request-to-indefinitely-detain-families/|title=Federal judge denies Trump administration's request to indefinitely detain families|last=Flynn|first=Meagan|date=July 10, 2018|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=July 10, 2018}}</ref> Gee wrote that, "Absolutely nothing prevents Defendants from reconsidering their current blanket policy of family detention and reinstating prosecutorial discretion."<ref name=":6" /><ref>Judge Dolly M. Gee, [https://www.politico.com/f/?id=00000164-8176-d66b-a166-8bf6cdaa0000 "Order Denying Defendant's 'Ex-Parte Application for Limited Relief from Settlement Agreement"], July 9, 2018.</ref>
=== August DHS complaint ===
On August 23, the [[American Immigration Lawyers Association]] and the [[American Immigration Council]] filed a complaint with DHS alleging the “pervasive, and illegal, practice of coercing separated mothers and fathers into signing documents they may not have understood.” According to the complaint, “the trauma of separation and detention creates an environment that is by its very nature coercive and makes it extremely difficult for parents to participate in legal proceedings affecting their rights.” It also describes the use of "physical and verbal threats, the denial of food and water, the use of solitary confinement, the use of starvation, restrictions on feminine-hygiene products, and the use of pre-filled forms."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Washington |first1=John |title=The Family-Separation Crisis Is Not Over |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/the-family-separation-crisis-is-not-over/ |website=The Nation |accessdate=October 4, 2018}}</ref>
=== Other challenges on behalf of individuals === Separately, a Guatemalan woman filed a federal lawsuit in the [[U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia]] in Washington challenging the Trump administration's practice on June 19, before the Executive Order. It is one of a small number of similar court challenges, with demands such as the immediate release of the child, an order prohibiting US authorities from separating the family, and money for damages of pain and suffering.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mejia-Mejia|first=Beata Mariana de Jesus|date=June 19, 2018|title=United States District Court, District of Columbia|url=https://www.politico.com/f/?id=00000164-19e0-d1bc-afef-5dfb78760000|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/19/family-separation-trump-administration-lawsuit-654822|title=New lawsuit challenges Trump administration over family separation|work=Politico|access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
Another lawsuit is that of a 9-year-old boy from [[Honduras]] who, according to the family, had fled with his father after his grandfather was murdered, was detained at the border and was separated from his father while sleeping. Another case is that of a 14-year-old girl who, so the lawsuit, had fled persecution in [[El Salvador]] and was lured away from her mother at a detention facility in Texas under the pretext of taking her to bathe. In both cases, the child was brought thousands of miles away.<ref>{{Cite news|first=Ana|last=Radelat|url=https://ctmirror.org/2018/07/05/two-immigrant-children-connecticut-sue-trump-administration-family-separations/|title=Two immigrant children in Connecticut sue over family separations|publisher=Connecticut Mirror|date=July 5, 2018|access-date=July 6, 2018}}</ref>
=== Federal class action lawsuit ===
On September 5, a federal lawsuit was filed to seek monetary damages on the basis of the inflicted psychological harm and the creation of a fund to support the mental health treatment of the children.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lawsuit Seeks Payout for Immigrant Families Separated at Border|periodical=|publisher=|url=https://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/national-international/Lawsuit-Seeks-Payout-for-Immigrant-Families-Separated-at-Border-492621531.html|deadurl=|accessdate=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=|pages=|quote=}}</ref>
== Facilities involved == === During separation === [[File:U.S. Border Patrol video shows holding facility in McAllen, Texas.webm|thumb|upright=1.2|'U.S. Border Patrol video shows holding facility in McAllen, Texas'. Video from [[Voice of America]]]]
* The [[Ursula (detention center)|Ursula detention facility]], operated by [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection|Customs and Border Protection]], in [[McAllen, Texas]], in the Rio Grande Valley—On June 17, the facility housed 1,129 people, including 528 families and nearly 200 unaccompanied minor children. The facility has been called, "the [[Kennel|dog kennel]]" because chain link fencing is being used to create areas for those waiting to be processed, including children who have been separated from their parents. The caged areas are bare without toys or books for the children. Oregon Senator [[Jeff Merkley]] toured the facility in June and said that the parents were being told that they would only be separated from their children for "just a very short period—they go to a judge and then they're reunified [but] the reality is it's very hard for the parents to know where their kids are and to be able to connect with them".<ref name="Carpenter">{{Cite news |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/like-inside-mcallen-border-patrol-facility/ |title=What It's Like Inside a Border Patrol Facility Where Families Are Being Separated |last=Carpenter |first=Zoë |date=June 18, 2018 |work=The Nation |access-date=June 18, 2018}}</ref>
=== Detention of parents === *[[Port Isabel Detention Center]], operated by [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|Immigration and Customs Enforcement]], in [[Los Fresnos, Texas]]—This facility is surrounded by swampland and houses detained parents. Several members of Congress toured the facility in June and met with 10 women who had been separated from their children. Some of them did not know where their children had been transferred to and none had been able to speak with a lawyer. One women said that she was told that her child would be put up for adoption. Rhode Island Representative [[David Cicilline]] said the women were uncontrollably sobbing.<ref name="Carpenter" /> *[[South Texas Detention Facility]], operated by the GEO Group, in [[Pearsall, Texas]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.expressnews.com/news/local/article/Government-moves-fitfully-secretly-to-reunite-13064936.php|title=Government moves fitfully, secretly to reunite sundered families|date=July 11, 2018|work=San Antonio Express-News|access-date=July 11, 2018}}</ref> *[[Eloy Detention Center]], owned and operated by [[CoreCivic]], in [[Eloy, Arizona]]—This privately run immigration jail is ringed by barbed wire and an electrified fence. In late May, detained parents had counted at least 40 people who had been separated from their children among the 1,500 people detained in the facility; Immigration and Customs Enforcement did not release its own figures.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/social-issues/inside-a-us-immigration-jail-mothers-count-the-days-since-theyve-seen-their-children/2018/06/28/6856d7ac-7a30-11e8-93cc-6d3beccdd7a3_story.html|title=Inside a U.S. immigration jail, mothers count the days since they've seen their children|last=Miller|first=Michael E.|date=|newspaper=The Washington Post|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wnyc.org/story/migrant-mom-poised-reunite-children-new-york-shares-detention-story/|title=Migrant Mom Poised to Reunite with Children Shares Detention Story|last=|first=|date=|publisher=WNYC|access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> *[[Northwest Detention Center]] in [[Tacoma, Washington]]—Adults separated from their child relatives were transferred to this facility, which suffered a chicken pox outbreak in late June, preventing a visit by Congressman Derek Kilmer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/texas/article/Politician-can-t-meet-with-detainees-due-to-pox-13023557.php|title=Latest: US official: Fort Bliss to house detained families|work=Beaumont Enterprise|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref>
=== Detention of children ===
*[[Casa Padre]], a private facility owned and operated by [[Southwest Key Programs]], in [[Brownsville, Texas]]—A housing facility for children built in a former Walmart and operated under contract for the Department of Health and Human Services. On June 13, it housed 1,469 children, a plurality of whom arrived as unaccompanied minors crossing the border. Southwest Key estimated that 5% of children held there had been separated from their parents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/inside-casa-padre-the-converted-walmart-where-the-us-is-holding-nearly-1500-immigrant-children/2018/06/14/0cd65ce4-6eba-11e8-bd50-b80389a4e569_story.html|title=Inside Casa Padre, the converted Walmart where the U.S. is holding nearly 1,500 immigrant children|last=Miller|first=Michael E.|date=June 14, 2018|work=The Washington Post |last2=Brown |first2=Emma |last3=Davis |first3=Aaron C. |access-date=June 18, 2018}}</ref> *Homestead Temporary Shelter for Unaccompanied Children in [[Homestead, Florida]]—A housing facility for around 1,100 children. Approximately 70 children separated from their families are housed at the facility.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2018/07/06/miami-republican-barred-from-visiting-immigrant-children-living-in-homestead-compound/|title=Miami Republican barred from visiting immigrant children living in Homestead compound |work=Tampa Bay Times|access-date=July 7, 2018}}</ref> The facility had been opened and closed during the Obama administration and was recently reopened.<ref name=":4" />[[File:Homestead_Florida_Unaccompanied_Minors.jpg|thumb|Unaccompanied minors walk in a Homestead, Florida, facility supervised by the Office of Refugee Resettlement, on June 20, 2018.]] *Estrella del Norte, a private facility owned and operated by Southwest Key Programs, in [[Tucson, Arizona]]—A 300-bed housing facility for children, that housed 287 children in mid-June 2018. A former staff member described conditions in the facility as increasingly "prison-like", and recounts being told to forbid siblings without their parent from hugging one another.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-border-migrant-shelter-20180614-story.html|title='Prison-like' migrant youth shelter is understaffed, unequipped for Trump's 'zero tolerance' policy, insider says|last=Hennessy-Fiske|first=Molly|date=June 14, 2018|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> *[[Tornillo tent city]], operated by the Federal government in [[Tornillo, Texas]]—Erected in the desert at the [[Marcelino Serna Port of Entry]] in western Texas. The site was chosen for a tent camp slated to house thousands of migrant children, including both unaccompanied minors and children separated from their parents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/06/14/tent-city-tornillo/|title=Trump administration makes site selection for tent city near El Paso to house immigrant children separated from parents|last=Parker|first=Claire|date=June 14, 2018|work=The Texas Tribune|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> Representative [[Beto O'Rourke]], who led a protest on Father's Day, June 17, 2018, was told that 200 children were being detained in the camp, 20% of whom were separated from their parents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/06/17/texas-beto-orourke-tent-city-tornillo-immigration/|title=Beto O'Rourke, Veronica Escobar lead Father's Day march on tent city housing separated immigrant children|last=Aguilar|first=Julian|date=June 17, 2018|work=The Texas Tribune |last2=García Hernández |first2=Juan Luis |access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> * Three facilities in [[Combes, Texas|Combes]], [[Raymondville, Texas|Raymondville]] and [[Brownsville, Texas|Brownsville]] (Casa El President, operated by [[Southwest Key]]), in southern Texas, have been set up to hold children under five and have been referred to as ''"tender age shelters"''. Medical professionals and lawyers who visited the facilities described "play rooms" filled with preschool children crying and in crisis.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/dc0c9a5134d14862ba7c7ad9a811160e|title=APNewsBreak: Youngest migrants held in 'tender age' shelters|publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref> Colleen Kraft, the president of [[American Academy of Pediatrics]], visited the Coombs facility and said she was "shaken" by what she saw, calling it "a heartbreaking scene" and unlike anything she'd seen in her decades as a pediatrician. She termed the practice of removing the children from their parents "government-sanctioned child abuse".<ref name="Doctors" /> [[File:Jacket Message Overshadows First Lady's Visit to Migrant Children.webm|thumb|right|200px|thumbtime=0:56|'Jacket Message Overshadows First Lady's Visit to Migrant Children', video from [[Voice of America]] ]] [[File:First Lady Melania Trump Visits Texas.webm|thumb|right|200px|'First Lady Melania Trump Visits Texas', video from the White House]] *Upbring New Hope Children’s Shelter in [[McAllen, Texas]]. As of June 21, about 60 children were housed in this facility, including six who had been separated from their parents while the remaining children had arrived alone. According to [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] President Colleen Draft, this center, like other centers, confiscates any possessions the child may arrive with and care givers are not allowed to comfort or touch the children. Following President Trump's June 20 executive order to stop separating undocumented immigrant parents and their children, on June 21 First Lady Melania Trump visited this facility saying, "I'm here to learn about your facility, in which I know you house children on a long-term basis and I'd also like to ask you how I can help these children to reunite with their families as quickly as possible." Critics have argued that this visit did not give the First Lady an accurate look at what many have called an unfolding crisis. She was also widely criticized for wearing a jacket that on the back stated "I Really Don't Care, Do U" when she boarded the plane for her trip to the facility.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/21/us/politics/melania-trump-jacket.html|last=Rogers|first=Katie|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 21, 2018|title=Melania Trump Wore a Jacket Saying 'I Really Don't Care' on Her Way to Texas Shelters|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=O'Connor |first1=Lydia |title=Melania Trump Visits Texas Shelter For Undocumented Children |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/melania-trump-visits-texas-shelter-181339458.html |publisher=HuffPost |accessdate=June 25, 2018}}</ref> *An [[East Harlem|East Harlem, New York]] shelter run by Cayuga Centers, Children's Village in [[Dobbs Ferry, New York]], and additional shelters in [[Long Island]], in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] and the [[The Bronx|Bronx]] are among nine facilities in New York state housing separated children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/20/nyregion/children-separated-border-new-york.html |title=Children Taken at the Border Arrive in New York|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> In a June 22 interview New York Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] said that he believes that HHS sent about 700 children to his state but he is not certain because HHS has refused to release any information about the children. The Governor said that he also contacted the [[foster care]] agencies in his state in an attempt to assess the number of children and to make sure that their needs were being met, but HHS had put a [[gag order]] on the agencies and they were not able to disclose any information either. He was allowed to visit one facility and the staff there told him that the children in their care "have a high level of psychological trauma [and] anxiety disorders".<ref>{{cite web |title=Governor Details Experience on CNN's New Day With John Berman |url=https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/video-governor-cuomo-visits-facility-housing-children-who-have-been-separated-their-parents |publisher=State of New York |accessdate=June 25, 2018}}</ref>
=== Proposed facilities === *'''Houston facility for young children, pregnant girls, and teenage mothers'''—[[Southwest Key]] has leased a 53,600-square-foot building—419 Emancipation Avenue—formerly occupied by the non-profit Star of Hope in [[Houston|Houston, Texas]], and applied to use it as a detention center for up to 200 migrant youth "from age 0 to 17".<ref name=Kriel>{{Cite news|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Immigrant-children-s-shelter-considered-for-12999084.php |title=Immigrant children's shelter considered for downtown Houston |last=Kriel |first=Lomi |date=June 15, 2018|work=Houston Chronicle|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> Advocates report that the facility would house "children younger than 12 as well as pregnant and nursing teenagers"; the Department of Health and Human Services refers to this younger age group as "tender-age children"<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/06/19/houston-southwest-key-undocumented-separated-children-immigration/|title=A facility to house immigrant children is planned for Houston. City officials don't want it.|last=Platoff|first=Emma|date=June 19, 2018|work=The Texas Tribune|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> Houston Mayor [[Sylvester Turner]] opposes the facility and has urged the Texas state government not to license it. At a press conference, Turner said, "I do not want to be an enabler in this process. I do not want the city to participate in this process. The health department has yet to provide a food permit or shelter permit.... If we don't speak, if we don't say no, then these types of policies will continue."<ref name=":02" /> *Military detention camp for migrant families at [[Fort Bliss]] *Military detention camp for migrant children on [[Goodfellow Air Force Base]]
== Procedures to reunite families == [[File:DHS-HaveYouBeenSeparatedFromChild(ren).jpg |thumb|A flyer circulated by the Department of Homeland Security in 2018 offering assistance to parents separated from their children while in custody.]]
Authorities made the decision to take children from their parents without a plan to reunite families,<ref name="KopanSpecificPlan"/> resulting in numerous cases of parents and children having no contact since being forcefully separated. One investigation reported that "The policy is being applied in such an opaque and ad hoc manner that government case workers, public defenders, federal prosecutors, judges, and the Border Patrol do not have clear answers about if, when, or where children will be reunited with their parents, or even whether separated parents are able to communicate with their kids by phone." When asked if separated parents will "just fall into a black hole" and be unable to reunite with their children unless they hire a lawyer, a Justice Department official replied that once the parent is in [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]] custody, the child is taken into the Health and Human Services system, and the government does not try to reunite them.<ref name=GoodwinTool>{{cite news |last1=Goodwin |first1=Liz |title='Children are being used as a tool' in Trump's effort to stop border crossings |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2018/06/09/borderseparations/Z95z4eFZjyfqCLG9pyHjAO/story.html |newspaper=The Boston Globe |accessdate=June 18, 2018}}</ref>
It was reported that if or when an attempt was made to reconnect children to their parents it would be difficult because children and parents entered two separate systems: parents entered the US Department of Homeland Security to face criminal prosecution while children were classified as an "unaccompanied alien child" and transferred to the US Department of Health and Human Services. At that point the government no longer tracked them as a family unit and there was no system in place to reunite families. In May, parents in the [[McAllen]] facility were given a number to call to locate their children, but it was the wrong number, and no phones were available for their use. A federal public defender working at the facility spoke to a judge asking that the families be reunited saying, "This is a tragedy that's happening right before this court. There's a very real possibility the parent will be deported without their children".<ref name=GoodwinTool/> John Sandweg, the former head of ICE, agreed saying, "You could easily end up in a situation where the gap between a parent's deportation and a child's deportation is years," and that many children might never see their parents again.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4284138/separation-children-parents-us-border-permanent/ |title=Separations of children, parents at U.S. border could be permanent: Former immigration director |date=June 19, 2018 |publisher=[[GlobalNews]] |first=Rebecca |last=Joseph }}</ref>
Representative [[Pramila Jayapal]] met with dozens of mothers whose children had been taken from them, and reported that in some cases, Border Patrol agents told the mothers that "their families don't exist anymore."<ref name="autogenerated2"/> ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' interviewed foster parents in [[Michigan]] who were caring for four children that had been taken from their parents; a six-year-old boy, two eight-year-old girls, and a nine-year-old boy. Only one of the children, the six-year-old, knew where his parent was. The boy and his father, from [[Honduras]], had crossed the border six months previously in an attempt to claim asylum, and he had not seen him since he had been led away in handcuffs.<ref name=GoodwinTool/> In May 2018, another Honduran man, Marco Antonio Muñoz, 39, committed suicide after his 3-year-old son was forcibly taken and separated from him by Border Patrol Agents. The man had crossed the [[Rio Grande]] with his son and his wife and turned himself and his family in to authorities to ask for asylum.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/a-family-was-separated-at-the-border-and-this-distraught-father-took-his-own-life/2018/06/08/24e40b70-6b5d-11e8-9e38-24e693b38637_story.html|title=A family was separated at the border, and this distraught father took his own life |first=Nick |last=Miroff|date=June 8, 2018|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
A journalist working for ''[[The New Yorker]]'' spoke with several women incarcerated at the [[Otero County Prison Facility|Otero County Prison]], a privately run facility in [[New Mexico]], and an attorney who is representing them. One mother tearfully said that she had no idea where her child might be and was concerned that his medical conditions were not being attended to. Another mother said that of the fifty mothers in her wing at Otero few knew where there children were. The public defender representing these mothers said, "The family-separation policy is changing the lawyer-client relationship. My clients don't even care about beating the charge they're facing. It makes it harder to represent them, because all they want is to be with their children. There can't really be due process for a parent in a situation like this."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Blitzer |first1=Jonathan |title=Mothers in a New Mexico Prison Do Not Know How to Find Their Children |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/dispatch/mothers-in-a-new-mexico-prison-do-not-know-how-to-find-their-children |website=The New Yorker |accessdate=June 22, 2018}}</ref>
Despite numerous reports of separations in which parents were not given information about their children,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Blitzer |first1=Jonathan |title=The Government Has No Plan for Reuniting the Immigrant Families It Is Tearing Apart |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-government-has-no-plan-for-reuniting-the-immigrant-families-it-is-tearing-apart |website=The New Yorker |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref> Senator [[James Lankford]], speaking on ''[[Meet the Press]]'' blamed "media that's not been responsible with this" for reports of difficulties locating parents or children. Calling the government personal working for the various agencies that have been handling the separations "professionals", he stated, "They know where every child is to be able to connect them to their parent or their relative that came."<ref>{{cite news |title=Meet the Press - June 24, 2018 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/meet-the-press/meet-press-june-24-2018-n886131 |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref>
Following a court order by District Judge [[Dana Sabraw]] to reunite all parents with their children by July 26, it was revealed that about 500 children's parents had already been deported. Judge Sabraw commented, "What was lost in the process was the family. The parents didn’t know where the children were, and the children didn’t know where the parents were. And the government didn’t know either.”<ref>{{cite web |title='Deleted’ families: What went wrong with Trump’s family-separation effort |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/social-issues/deleted-families-what-went-wrong-with-trumps-family-separation-effort/2018/07/28/54bcdcc6-90cb-11e8-8322-b5482bf5e0f5_story.html?utm_term=.be794d7d9ba5 |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=August 4, 2018}}</ref> On August 2, the Justice Department filed in court that the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) should take responsibility for reuniting families, rather than the federal government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/08/03/trump-administration-puts-burden-on-aclu-to-find-deported-parents-separated-from-children/|title=Trump administration puts burden on ACLU to find deported parents separated from children|last=Schmidt|first=Samantha|date=August 3, 2018|website=Washington Post|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 3, 2018}}</ref> The ACLU responded by stating that while they are ready to help, the burden of responsibility for finding parents of minors separated at the border was the government's responsibility.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/03/politics/trump-administration-aclu-deported-parents/index.html|title=Judge slams Trump admin for suggesting ACLU, others should find deported parents|last=Kopan|first=Tal|date=August 3, 2018|work=CNN|access-date=August 3, 2018|last2=Chavez|first2=Nicole}}</ref>
== Reactions == === Opposition and condemnation === [[File:Rally_to_end_Family_Separation_Cleveland-04.jpg|thumb|A protester compares child detention by the government to the [[Nazi concentration camps]]]] [[File:Follow_Free_Our_Future._Families_Belong_Together._Abolish_ICE._March_and_Day_of_Action.jpg|thumb|About 10,000 people gathered downtown Minneapolis and marched through the streets to protest against immigrant children being taken from their families]]
The policy attracted significant condemnation from a wide array of sources including medical, scientific, religious and human rights groups. It is extremely unpopular with the public, with approximately 25% of Americans supporting the policy, less than any recent major piece of legislation.<!-- this is a policy, but it is compared here to legislation, is that correct? --><ref name=Sides/> The detainment of children by the U.S. government has been compared to the [[Nazi concentration camps]] by some observers and politicians.<ref>Mallory Shelbourne. [http://thehill.com/latino/392727-hayden-sees-commonality-between-zero-tolerance-border-policy-and-nazi-germany "Hayden sees 'commonality' between zero-tolerance border policy and Nazi Germany"]. ''The Hill'' (June 18, 2018).</ref><ref>Emma Teitel. [https://www.thestar.com/opinion/star-columnists/2018/06/20/nazi-germany-comparisons-with-family-separation-in-us-are-fair-comment.html "Nazi Germany comparisons with family separation in U.S. are fair comment"]. ''The Star'' (June 20, 2018).</ref>
====Medical and scientific community==== The policy has been condemned by the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]], the [[American College of Physicians]] and the [[American Psychiatric Association]], with the American Academy of Pediatrics saying that the policy has caused "irreparable harm" to the children.<ref name="Doctors" /><ref name=":78" /><ref>American Psychological Association. (June 14, 2018). ''Open Letter to President Donald Trump.'' http://www.apa.org/advocacy/immigration/separating-families-letter.pdf</ref> Together, they represent more than 250,000 doctors in the United States.<ref name="Doctors"/> Pediatrician [[Nadine Burke Harris]] described the family separation policy as "a recipe for [[toxic stress]]".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/2018/06/08/290091/doctors-say-kids-separated-from-parents-at-border-face-toxic-stress-serious-health-risks/ |title=Doctors Say Kids Separated From Parents At Border Face 'Toxic Stress', Serious Health Risks |publisher=Houston Public Media |author=Ashley Lopez |date=June 8, 2018 |accessdate=June 22, 2018}}</ref> Dr. Irwin Redlener, who co-founded [[Children's Health Fund]], called the policy "dehumanizing" and described it as a form of [[child abuse]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.msnbc.com/ali-velshi/watch/-this-is-child-abuse-by-government-says-dr-irwin-redlener-1256853059535 |title='This is child abuse by government', says Dr. Irwin Redlener |publisher=MSNBC|date=June 15, 2018}}</ref> A number of concerned researchers and clinicians signed an open letter to Homeland Security Secretary Nielsen calling on her to end the migrant child separations, writing, "Decades of psychological and brain research have demonstrated that forced parental separation and placement in incarceration-like facilities can have profound immediate, long-term, and irreparable harm on infant and child development."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/view/letter-to-secretary-nielsen/home?authuser=0|title=Open Letter from Concerned Scientists on Migrant Child Separation|via=sites.google.com|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
==== Religious groups ====
Many religious groups also oppose the policy including many Christian organizations such as: * The [[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]] * The [[National Association of Evangelicals]]<ref name="abcnews1">{{cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/religious-leaders-implore-trump-white-house-stop-separating/story?id=55905666|title=Religious groups implore Trump White House: Stop separating immigrant families |date=June 15, 2018|publisher=ABC News|access-date=June 15, 2018}}</ref> * The [[Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Papagermanos |first1=Steve |title=Archdiocese Statement in Defense of Children and Families |url=https://www.goarch.org/-/archdiocese-statement-in-defense-of-children-and-families |publisher=Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America |accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref> * [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] * [[United Methodist Church]] * [[African Methodist Episcopal Church]] * [[Presbyterian Church (USA)|Presbyterian Church]] * [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America|Evangelical Lutheran Church]] * [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]<ref>{{cite press release|title=Church Statement on Separation of Families at the US-Mexico Border|url=https://www.mormonnewsroom.org/article/church-statement-separation-of-families-at-us-mexico-border |publisher=Mormon Newsroom |date=June 18, 2018|accessdate=June 29, 2018}}</ref>
In response to a criticism of the policy by a cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church, Attorney General Jeff Sessions defended the policy, citing the Bible.<ref name="Long" /><ref name=Zauzmer15 />
On June 18, a group of more than 600 [[United Methodist Church]] clergy and laity announced that they were bringing [[Ecclesiastical court#United Methodist Church|church law charges]] against Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]]. The members of the group accused Sessions of "child abuse, immorality, racial discrimination and dissemination of doctrines contrary to the standards of the doctrine of the United Methodist Church".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wsfa.com/story/38450661/faith-leaders-call-family-separation-cruel-and-detrimental|title=Hundreds of United Methodist clergy bring church charges against Jeff Sessions|publisher=WSFA 12 News |accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref> The last charge refers to Sessions' "misuse" of [[Romans 13]], which he quoted to argue that secular law must always be obeyed.<ref>{{cite web |author=640 laity and clergy of the United Methodist Church |url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/Website_Properties/news-media/documents/A_Complaint_regarding_Jefferson_Sessions.pdf |title=A Complaint regarding Jefferson Sessions |date=July 18, 2018 |accessdate=July 6, 2018}}</ref>
All four major denominations of American Judaism oppose the policy: * [[Union for Reform Judaism|Reform]] * [[United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism|Conservative]] * [[Orthodox Union|Orthodox]] * [[Reconstructionist Judaism|Reconstructionist]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.jta.org/2018/06/17/news-opinion/united-states/orthodox-union-joins-jewish-communal-letter-opposing-family-separations|title=Orthodox Union joins Jewish communal letter opposing family separations|publisher=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|date=June 17, 2018}}</ref>
Islamic organizations also oppose the policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://advocacy.episcopalchurch.org/app/document/28873301?0|title=Presiding Bishop Michael Curry Joins Other Faith Leaders in a Statement on Family Separation at Our Borders|publisher=Office of Government Relations, [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]]|date=June 13, 2018}}</ref>
[[Pope Francis]] supports statements by US Catholic Bishops who had called the policy "contrary to our Catholic values" and "immoral", adding "It's not easy, but [[populism]] is not the solution."<ref>{{cite news|title=Pope Francis Slams Trump's Family Separation Policy As 'Immoral'|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/pope-francis-trump-family-separation_us_5b2a3458e4b0a4dc9922a221|agency=Reuters|publisher=[[HuffPost]]|date=June 20, 2018|access-date=June 29, 2018}}</ref>
Evangelist [[Franklin Graham]], son of evangelist [[Billy Graham]], called the practice "disgraceful" and said that "it's terrible to see families ripped apart and I don't support that one bit." Graham did not, however, attach blame to President Trump or his administration, but rather blamed "... the politicians for the last 20, 30 years that have allowed this to escalate to where it is today".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/14/us/trump-immigration-religion.html |title=Conservative Religious Leaders Are Denouncing Trump Immigration Policies|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 14, 2018}}</ref>
==== Academia ==== Many professors and administrators in colleges and universities have likened the policy to the [[internment of Japanese Americans]] during World War II.<ref name="CHE">{{Cite news|url=https://www.chronicle.com/article/College-LeadersProfessors/243714|title=College Leaders and Professors Ramp Up Protest of Trump's Family-Separation Policy|date=June 19, 2018|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> Open letters signed by various scholars denounced the policy and called for its halt.<ref name="CHE"/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/1imbob01ErX1NVY6JC_wmlnxfea3MmWUa/view|title=Letter to DHS from Faculty.pdf|via=Google Docs|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
====Civil rights and humanitarian groups==== A large number of civil rights groups, humanitarian organizations, and other groups condemned the family separation policy, including the [[Anti-Defamation League]], the [[Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law]], the [[League of Women Voters of the United States]], the [[International Rescue Committee]], the [[NAACP]], and the [[National Immigration Law Center]].<ref>[http://civilrightsdocs.info/pdf/policy/letters/2018/Org%20Letter%20to%20President%20Trump%20re%20Family%20Separation%2006-08-2018.pdf Letter to President Trump from National, State, and Local Organizations], [[Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights]] (June 8, 2018).</ref>
The [[Tahirih Justice Center]] has criticized that the policy of charging asylum seekers with a criminal offense, and subsequent separation of families, is contrary to [[Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees#The contracting states shall not|Article 31 of the Refugee Convention]]. This Article prohibits any party to the Convention from imposing penalties on asylum seekers on account of their illegal entry or presence, provided the asylum seekers present themselves without delay to the authorities and show good cause for their illegal entry or presence.<ref name="texasmonthly-2018-06-15"/> Thus according to international law, such asylum seekers are not liable to criminal prosecution for illegal entry. The United States ratified the 1967 Protocol of the Refugee Convention in 1968, and thereby obliged itself to adhere to Articles 2 through 34 of the Convention.<ref>{{cite web|first1=Joan|last1=Fitzpatrick|url=https://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1154&context=bjil|title=The International Dimension of U.S. Refugee Law|access-date=July 3, 2018}} Footnote 1 on page 1.</ref>
The director for the Americas at the International Secretariat of [[Amnesty International]], [[Erika Guevara Rosas]], has stated that the "severe mental suffering that officials have intentionally inflicted on these families for coercive purposes, means that these acts meet the definitions of [[torture]] under both US and international law".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2018/06/usa-family-separation-torture/|title=USA: Policy of separating children from parents is nothing short of torture|publisher=Amnesty International|date=June 19, 2018|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref>
====Congress ==== Forty Democratic United States Senators sent a letter to President Trump urging him to "rescind this unethical, ineffective, and inhumane policy and instead prioritize approaches that align with our humanitarian and American values".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2018/06/15/nelson-rubio-oppose-breaking-up-immigrant-families/|title=Nelson, Rubio oppose breaking up immigrant families|last=Leary|first=Alex|work=Tampa Bay Times|date=June 15, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billnelson.senate.gov/sites/default/files/20180607%20Dem%20Letter%20to%20Trump%20Child%20Separation.pdf|title=Letter to President Donald Trump from 40 Democratic U.S. Senators on Child Separation|date=June 7, 2018}}</ref> In response to the policy, Senator [[Dianne Feinstein]] introduced a bill, Keep Families Together Act (S. 3036), under which the separation of a child from its parents would only be allowed under very specific conditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/3036|title=S.3036 – Keep Families Together Act|publisher=U.S. Congress |accessdate=June 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>Justin L. Mack, [https://www.indystar.com/story/news/2018/06/18/sen-joe-donnelly-cosponsor-keep-families-together-act-immigration-reform/709409002/ Sen. Joe Donnelly cosponsoring bill to fight separation of families at the border], ''Indianapolis Star'' (June 18, 2018).</ref><ref>Kathryn Watson, [https://www.cbsnews.com/news/feinstein-says-shes-introduced-bill-to-keep-immigrant-families-together/ Feinstein says she's introduced bill to keep immigrant families together], CBS News (June 8, 2018).</ref> By June 18, the entire Democratic caucus of 49 senators (including the two independents who caucus with the Democrats) had signed on as cosponsors.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/sen-joe-manchin-the-final-democratic-holdout-signs-onto-bill-to-stop-family-separations|title=Sen. Joe Manchin, the Final Democratic Holdout, Signs Onto Bill to Stop Family Separations|last=Resnick|first=Gideon|date=June 18, 2018|publisher=The Daily Beast|access-date=June 18, 2018}}</ref>
Republicans in Congress fell into four groups on the child-separation policy: *The vast majority of Republicans in Congress kept silent on the policy, seeking to avoid a confrontation with Trump.<ref name="Phillips">Amber Phillips, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/06/19/is-trump-losing-his-support-in-congress-for-separating-families-at-the-border/ How Republicans are divided over Trump's immigration policy: For it, against it and keeping their mouths shut], ''The Washington Post'' (June 19, 2018).</ref> *Other congressional Republicans, such as Representative [[Steve King]] of [[Iowa]], supported separating families.<ref name="Phillips"/> *Some congressional Republicans, such as Senator [[Dean Heller]] of [[Nevada]] and Representative [[Kevin Cramer]] of [[North Dakota]], expressed disagreement with the policy but avoid strongly criticizing Trump.<ref name="Phillips"/> *Another group of congressional Republicans were strongly critical of the policy, including members who are frequent Trump critics (for example, Senators [[Jeff Flake]], [[John McCain]], [[Ben Sasse]], and [[Susan Collins]]), but also some who are usually aligned with Trump (for example, Senator [[Orrin Hatch]]).<ref name="Phillips"/>
Republican Senator [[Ted Cruz]] initially defended the policy in an June 11 interview.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/391699-cruz-defends-trump-policy-of-family-separation|title=Cruz defends Trump policy of family separation|last=Sanchez|first=Luis|date=June 11, 2018|work=The Hill|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> On June 18, despite his previous support of the policy, Cruz announced that he would introduce his own legislation, criticizing the Democrats' bill as "returning to the failed policy of '[[Catch and release (immigration practice)|catch and release]]{{'"}}.<ref name=Krisitian>{{Cite news|url=https://theweek.com/speedreads/779979/ted-cruz-introduces-bill-curtail-migrant-family-separation-must-stop-now|title=Ted Cruz introduces bill to curtail migrant family separation: 'This must stop. Now.' |last=Krisitian |first=Bonnie|date=June 19, 2018|publisher=The Week |access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> Cruz stated that his bill would end the separation policy by authorizing the construction of shelters to house families, expedite asylum cases, and increase the number of federal immigration judges.<ref name=Krisitian/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kfoxtv.com/news/local/cruz-promises-bill-to-deal-with-border-crisis|title=Cruz promises bill to deal with border crisis|last=|first=|date=|publisher=KFOX|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> [[Senate Minority Leader]] [[Chuck Schumer]] criticized Cruz's proposal, arguing that the Republicans would include "unacceptable additions" and instead urged Trump to end the policy using an executive order.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/393069-schumer-rejects-gop-proposal-to-address-border-crisis?amp&__twitter_impression=true|title=Schumer rejects GOP proposal to address border crisis|last=Balluck|first=Kyle|date=June 19, 2018|work=The Hill|access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
====Governors==== In early 2018, Trump requested that [[Governor (United States)|state governors]] send [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] troops to the U.S.-Mexico border. In response to the family-separation policy, at least eight governors either recalled [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] troops from the U.S.-Mexico border or declined to send them to the border. States that withdrew troops, reversed plans to send troops, or declined to send troops were [[New York (state)|New York]], [[North Carolina]], [[Virginia]], [[Colorado]], [[Delaware]], and [[Rhode Island]] (which have Democratic governors) and [[Maryland]] and [[Massachusetts]] (which have Republican governors).<ref name="HaagBidgood">Matthew Haag & Jess Bidgood, [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/19/us/national-guard-trump-children-immigration.html Governors Refuse to Send National Guard to Border, Citing Child Separation Practice], ''The New York Times'' (June 19, 2018).</ref> Democratic Governor [[John Carney (politician)|John Carney]] of Delaware, for example, said "Under normal circumstances, we wouldn't hesitate to answer the call. But given what we know about the policies currently in effect at the border, I can't in good conscience send Delawareans to help with that mission."<ref name="HaagBidgood"/> (Some additional states—Vermont and Oregon—had declined Trump's request before the family-separation policy had been implemented.)<ref name="HaagBidgood"/>
Among Republican governors, some supported Trump's policy of separating families (Phil Bryant of Mississippi, Henry McMaster of South Carolina), while others opposed the policy ([[Pete Ricketts]] of Nebraska, [[Bruce Rauner]] of Illinois, [[John Kasich]] of [[Ohio]]).<ref name="HaagBidgood"/><ref name=Higgins>{{cite news | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/19/5-governors-wont-keep-national-guard-on-the-border.html | title=At least 5 governors won't keep National Guard on the southern border, citing Trump's family separation policy | publisher=[[CNBC]] | date=June 19, 2018 | last=Higgins | first=Tucker | accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
==== UN and international bodies ==== The policy has also been condemned by the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]].<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref name="press1"/> High Commissioner [[Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein]] called it an "unconscionable" effort by a state to deter parents by abusing children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/06/un-human-rights-chief-family-separations-forced-by-trump-administration-are-child-abuse/|title=The UN human rights chief just accused Donald Trump of child abuse|work=Mother Jones|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref>
[[United Nations special rapporteur]]s from the [[United Nations Human Rights Council|Human Rights Council]] have also condemned the policy, and have stated that detention of children "is punitive, severely hampers their development, and in some cases may amount to torture". The rapporteurs have called its rescission insufficient.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/un-trump-children-family-torture-separation-border-mexico-border-ice-detention-a8411676.html|title=UN says Trump separation of migrant children from parents 'may amount to torture'|work=The Independent|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ochre-2018-06-22">{{cite web|url=https://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=23245&LangID=E|publisher=OHCHR |title=UN experts to US: 'Release migrant children from detention and stop using them to deter irregular migration' |access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref>
The [[Inter-American Commission on Human Rights]] has formally requested additional information from the U.S. government on the location and plans for affected children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sacurrent.com/the-daily/archives/2018/06/25/the-inter-american-commission-on-human-rights-demands-answers-from-trump-administration-over-separation-of-families-separated-in-texas|title=The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights Demands Answers from Trump Administration over Separation of Families Separated in Texas|last=Nowlin|first=Sanford|work=San Antonio Current|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref>
====Others==== All four living former [[First Ladies of the United States]]—[[Rosalynn Carter]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Laura Bush]], and [[Michelle Obama]]—condemned the policy of separating children from their parents.<ref>Matt Stevens & Sarah Mervosh, [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/19/us/politics/first-ladies-trump-family-separation.html All 4 Living Former First Ladies Condemn Trump Border Policy That Separates Families], ''The New York Times'' (June 19, 2018).</ref> First Lady [[Melania Trump]]'s office issued a statement saying, "[Mrs. Trump] believes we need to be a country that follows all laws, but also a country that governs with heart."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/17/politics/melania-trump-children-separated-immigration/index.html|title=Melania Trump 'hates to see' children separated from their families at borders |author=Kate Bennett |publisher=CNN|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> Laura Bush wrote an op-ed in [[The Boston Globe]] condemning the use of practices "reminiscent of the internment camps for U.S. citizens and noncitizens of Japanese descent during World War II, now considered to have been one of the most shameful episodes in U.S. history.<ref>{{cite news |author=Laura Bush |title=Separating children from their parents at the border 'breaks my heart' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/laura-bush-separating-children-from-their-parents-at-the-border-breaks-my-heart/2018/06/17/f2df517a-7287-11e8-9780-b1dd6a09b549_story.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref>
A bipartisan group of 75 former [[U.S. attorneys]] published an [[open letter]] to Attorney General Jeff Sessions, calling for an end to the policy, writing that the policy inflicts "unnecessary trauma and suffering of innocent children" and "is a radical departure from previous Justice Department policy" that "is dangerous, expensive, and inconsistent with the values of the institution in which we served".<ref name="Miller">Hayley Miller, [https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/us-attorneys-jeff-sessions-family-separation_us_5b28ef60e4b0a4dc9920a0ba 75 Former U.S. Attorneys To Jeff Sessions: End Inhumane Family Separation Policy Now], HuffPost (June 19, 2018).</ref><ref name="USALtr">[https://medium.com/@formerusattorneys/bipartisan-group-of-former-united-states-attorneys-call-on-sessions-to-end-child-detention-e129ae0df0cf Bipartisan Group of Former United States Attorneys Call on Sessions to End Family Separation], ''Medium'' (June 19, 2018).</ref> The former U.S. attorneys also pointed out that the policy is not required by law.<ref name="Miller"/><ref name="USALtr"/>
[[Fox News]] commentator [[Andrew Napolitano]] has criticised the policy, stating that he believes that "it is child abuse to separate children from their parents unless it's necessary to save a human life ... there's a federal statute that says you can't separate them more than 72 hours."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mediaite.com/tv/andrew-napolitano-says-trump-is-trying-to-use-children-as-negotiating-chip-its-child-abuse/|title=Andrew Napolitano: Trump is 'Trying to Use Children' as Negotiating Chip, Policy is 'Child Abuse'|publisher=mediaite |access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> News anchor [[Jorge Ramos (news anchor)|Jorge Ramos]] declared that the policy violated both Article 1 of the [[United Nations Convention against Torture]] (UNCAT) that forbids torture, and Article 9 of the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] (CRC) that states that a child shall not be separated from his or her parents against their will. The US has signed and ratified the UNCAT, and signed but not yet ratified the CRC.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://time.com/5317551/family-separation-policy-torture/|title=Jorge Ramos: Yes, the Family Separation Policy Is Torture|publisher=TIME|date=June 20, 2018|access-date=July 6, 2018}}</ref>
Family separations were widely condemned in the business community, including by conservative groupings like the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]] and the [[Business Roundtable]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/19/us/politics/trump-immigration-children-separated-families.html|title=G.O.P. Moves to End Trump's Family Separation Policy, but Can't Agree How|access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/19/a-koch-backed-group-and-other-business-leaders-are-calling-on-trump-to-end-policy-on-family-separation.html|title=Trump should end policy on family separation, says Koch-backed group and business leaders|last=Schwartz|first=Brian|date=June 19, 2018|publisher=CNBC|access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
