On June 20, three airlines – [[American Airlines]], [[United Airlines]] and [[Frontier Airlines]] – each issued a statement requesting the federal government not to use their planes to transport migrant children who were taken from their parents.<ref>{{cite news |author=Jackie Wattles, Rene Marsh|url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/06/20/news/companies/american-airlines-children-detention-border-trump/index.html|title=Airlines ask the government not to fly separated children on their planes|publisher=CNNMoney |date=June 20, 2018|access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref> The previous day, a veteran flight attendant for a major airline recounted an episode in which an [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]] agent initially told another flight attendant that the migrant children on their flight were members of a soccer team, but "when pressed, the agent finally admitted that they were, indeed children who were being relocated to assigned camps".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/local/gray-matters/article/Flight-attendant-I-won-t-work-flights-that-13008372.php|title=Flight attendant: I won't work flights that separate immigrant kids from families|newspaper=Houston Chronicle |accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
==== Protests ==== [[File:Rally_to_end_Family_Separation_Cleveland-03.jpg|thumb|Rally to end family separation in [[Cleveland]], Ohio (June 30, 2018)]] {{main|Protests against Trump administration family separation policy}} Beginning in June, protests were held in numerous cities across the nation as plans for a larger nation-wide protests were being formulated. On June 30, a national protest organized by the newly-formed group "Keep Families Together" was held which drew hundreds of thousands of protesters from all 50 states to demonstrate in more than 600 towns and cities. Approximately 30,000 marchers crossing the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] in New York City, chanted, "Immigrants built this bridge." Some demonstration speakers stressed the urgent need for political activism. In Atlanta Representative [[John Lewis (civil rights leader)|John Lewis]] spoke saying, "We've got to get out and vote like we never voted before." [[Lin-Manuel Miranda]] performed for the protesters, singing a song from his musical ''Hamilton'', and commented, "We will not stand for a country separating children from their families, and if you are silent on that issue, or you are somehow for that issue you're not getting re-elected."<ref name="nbcnews1"/>
==== Fundraising response ====
Inspired by the [[John Moore photograph of Honduran child|viral photo of a crying two-year-old girl looking up at her mother]], on June 16, 2018, a California couple started a fund-raising campaign on [[Facebook]] named "Reunite an immigrant parent with their child" with a goal of raising $1,500.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wfaa.com/article/news/nation-now/facebook-fundraiser-to-help-immigrant-children-tops-17-million-with-donations-from-around-the-world/465-1d7fe37e-e88c-4dd4-b984-2f7acfe24241|title=Facebook fundraiser to help immigrant children tops $17 million with donations from around the world|last=|first=|date=|publisher=WFAA|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref> Within the first few days the campaign was raising over $4,000 a minute and in a little over a week's time it had raised over $20 million, breaking a Facebook record for donations.<ref>{{cite news |title=The campaign raising money to reunite immigrant families has topped $20 million. It's on to $25 million now |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/25/us/raices-fundraiser-20-million-trnd/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=June 28, 2018}}</ref> The money will go to the [[Refugee and Immigrant Center for Education and Legal Services]], or RAICES, and provide legal aid for immigrant parents who have been arrested at the border.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hutchinson |first1=Bill |title=Facebook campaign tops $4 million to reunite immigrant families separated at border |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/facebook-campaign-tops-million-reunite-immigrant-families-separated/story?id=55997665 |publisher=ABC |accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref>
The photograph was taken by professional photographer, John Moore, just after the mother was asked to set her child down to be body-searched before boarding the Border Patrol van and the little girl began to cry. The mother is from [[Honduras]] and had been traveling for a month.<ref>{{cite news |title=This 2-year-old has become the face of 'zero tolerance' |url=https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2018/06/us/crying-girl-john-moore-immigration-cnnphotos/ |publisher=CNN |accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref> The photo raised controversy after the father of the child said in an interview that the mother and daughter were now being detained together in McAllen, Texas. This has caused many in Trump's administration to rally against "fake news" with [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders|White House Spokeswoman Sarah Sanders]] tweeting that the Democrats and media "exploited this photo of a little girl to push their own agenda".<ref name="BBC22">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-44578339|title=Child migrant photo 'not what it seemed'|date=June 22, 2018|publisher=BBC News|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref>
====Public opinion ==== The family-separation policy is unpopular among Americans, as shown by four polls; on average, two-thirds of Americans oppose the policy.<ref name="Mehta">Dhrumil Mehta, [https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/separating-families-at-the-border-is-really-unpopular/ Separating Families At The Border Is Really Unpopular], [[FiveThirtyEight]] (June 19, 2018).</ref><ref name="cnnpollseparation">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/18/politics/immigration-trump-approval/index.html|title=Majority oppose policy that causes family separation, but Republicans approve|last=Sparks|first=Grace|publisher=CNN |accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Quinnipiacpollseparation">{{cite web|url=https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=2550|title=QU Poll Release Detail|publisher=Quinnipiac University |accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref> There is a strong partisan divide; the average of polls showed that Democrats are overwhelmingly opposed to the policy (8% support, 87% oppose, 5% other) while a plurality of Republicans favor it (49% support, 35% oppose, 16% other).<ref name="Mehta"/> Trump's approval rating fell to 41 percent, with a 55 percent disapproval rating according to a Gallup poll following increased public awareness of the policy.<ref name=Jones>{{cite web | url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/235955/trump-job-approval-slips-back.aspx?g_source=link_NEWSV9&g_medium=LEAD&g_campaign=item_&g_content=Trump%2520Job%2520Approval%2520Slips%2520Back%2520to%252041%2525 | title=Trump Job Approval Slips Back to 41% | publisher=Gallup | date=June 25, 2018 | last=Jones | first=Jeffrey | accessdate=June 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Goodkind>{{cite news | url=http://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-approval-rating-migrant-children-994971 | title=Donald Trump's Approval Rating Sees Record-equaling Drop Amid Migrant Children Separation Crisis | publisher=[[Newsweek]] | date=June 25, 2018 | last=Goodkind | first=Nicole | accessdate=June 26, 2018}}</ref>
====White House==== According to a report by [[Gabriel Sherman]], the policy caused "chaos" and infighting among the White House staff and advisers. [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] was "frustrated" according to one of her friends. On the other hand, according to one White House adviser, [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]] "actually enjoys seeing those pictures at the border", referring to the photographs of children separated from their parents.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2018/06/stephen-miller-family-separation-white-house/amp|title='Stephen Actually Enjoys Seeing Those Pictures at the Border': The West Wing Is Fracturing Over Trump's Callous Migrant-Family Policy|publisher=Vanity Fair |accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref>
=== Support === [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders|White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders]], [[Chuck Grassley|Senator Chuck Grassley]] and [[Paul Ryan|House Speaker Paul Ryan]] have asserted that the Trump administration are required to separate migrant families due to the 1997 [[Reno v. Flores|''Flores'' settlement]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/sites/default/files/assets/flores_settlement_final_plus_extension_of_settlement011797.pdf|title=Reno vs. Flores|date=January 7, 1997|publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]]|accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Qiu>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/14/us/politics/fact-check-republicans-family-separations-border.html |title=Republicans Misplace Blame for Splitting Families at the Border |first=Linda |last=Qiu |date=June 14, 2018 }}</ref> which requires that unaccompanied minors be released to their parents or relatives, and if a relative cannot be found then a government agency can appoint an appropriate guardian for the child.<ref name=Qiu/><ref name=RealityCheck>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-44303556 |title=Who decided to separate illegal immigrant families? |date=June 19, 2018 |publisher=BBC News |author=Reality Check |access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> Trump administration officials also cited the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA), a 2008 anti-human trafficking statute, as a justification for the policy.<ref name=RealityCheck/> Neither the ''Flores'' settlement nor the TVPRA, however, require or recommend family separations.<ref name=RealityCheck/><ref name=Rizzo/>
Following President Trump's executive order ending family separation [[David A. French|David French]] criticized the Democrat's position saying, "those of us with a trace of historical memory know that the Trump administration is merely asking the courts and Congress to adopt the Obama administration’s legal position.[...]But despite this victory, Democrats are still furious. It’s not enough to stop child separation. Now, they want to prevent family detention entirely."<ref>{{cite web |last1=French |first1=David |title=Trump Moves to Obama’s Position on Family Detention, Democrats Outraged |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2018/06/donald-trump-family-separation-executive-order-obama-policy/ |website=National Review |accessdate=August 3, 2018}}</ref>
Conservative commentator [[Ann Coulter]] on June 17 dismissed immigrant children as "child actors weeping and crying" and urged Trump not to "fall for it".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Thomsen |first1=Jacqueline |title=Ann Coulter calls immigrant children 'child actors' |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/media/392774-ann-coulter-calls-immigrant-children-child-actors |newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref> Fox News television host [[Laura Ingraham]] on June 18 described the facilities where migrant children were housed as "essentially summer camps".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/media/392922-laura-ingraham-describes-child-detention-centers-as-essentially-summer-camps|title=Laura Ingraham: Migrant child detention centers 'essentially summer camps'|last=Anapol|first=Avery|date=June 18, 2018|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/laura-ingraham-immigrant-summer-camp_us_5b28b769e4b0f0b9e9a4840c|title=Laura Ingraham Compares Child Immigrant Detention Centers To Summer Camps|last=Frej|first=Willa|date=June 19, 2018|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> She described criticism of the immigration policies as "faux liberal outrage".<ref>{{cite news |title=Ingraham: Trump Enforcing Immigration Laws Long 'Ignored and Unenforced' |url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2018/06/18/ingraham-angle-trump-enforcing-immigration-laws-border |publisher=[[Fox News]] |accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref> Also on June 18, conservative commentator and author [[Ben Shapiro]] pointed to the 2016 [[Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] ruling in ''[[Flores v. Lynch]]'', which he said "meant that the government either had to release whole families, or that the government had to separate parents from children".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shapiro |first1=Ben |title=The Media Are Lying About Trump Separating Illegal Immigrant Families. Here's The Truth. |url=https://www.dailywire.com/news/31979/media-are-lying-about-trump-separating-illegal-ben-shapiro |publisher=The Daily Wire |accessdate=June 21, 2018 |date=June 18, 2018}}</ref>
''[[Fox & Friends]]'' co-host [[Brian Kilmeade]] defended Trump's family separation policy, arguing that migrant children are being treated as though they are more important than "people in our country who pay taxes and have needs as well." He states, "Like it or not, these aren't our kids. Show them compassion, but it's not like [Trump is] doing this to the people of Idaho or Texas. These are people from another country."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/latino/393616-fox-friends-host-on-separated-children-these-arent-our-kids |title='Fox & Friends' host on detained children: 'These aren't our kids' |newspaper=The Hill |date=June 22, 2018 |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref>
=== Trump administration response === On June 19, 2018, a fact checker for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' critiqued a number of statements by Trump and members of his administration, characterizing them as "[[Orwellian|Orwellian stuff]]" and designating them as Four Pinocchios — the Post's highest rating of falsehood.<ref name=Rizzo>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2018/06/19/the-facts-about-trumps-policy-of-separating-families-at-the-border/|title=Analysis – The facts about Trump's policy of separating families at the border|first=Salvador|last=Rizzo|date=June 19, 2018|website=The Washington Post |accessdate=June 19, 2018}}</ref> The Trump administration had offered at least 14 contradictory statements about its policy, including contradictions about whether it was a Justice Department policy, whether separations are a deterrent, whether there was a prepared process to separate families, and whether separations are required by law. Trump has also said that he could not reverse his administration's policy via executive order, while later writing an executive order to reverse the policy.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rieger |first1=JM |title=The Trump administration changed its story on family separation no fewer than 14 times before ending the policy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/06/20/the-trump-administration-changed-its-story-on-family-separation-no-fewer-than-14-times-before-ending-the-policy/ |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=June 23, 2018}}</ref>
==== President Trump ==== President Trump said in response to the situation: "I hate to see separation of parents and children ... I hate the children being taken away." Trump has blamed the Democrats for "that law" (also calling it "their law"<ref name=Davis/> and "the horrible law"<ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |number=1000375761604370434 |date=May 26, 2018 |title=Put pressure on the Democrats to end the horrible law that separates children from there parents once they cross the Border into the U.S. Catch and Release, Lottery and Chain must also go with it and we MUST continue building the WALL! DEMOCRATS ARE PROTECTING MS-13 THUGS.}}</ref>) on a number of occasions despite there being no law to mandate the separation of migrant parents and children.<ref>{{cite news |first1=Tal |last1=Kopan |first2=Lauren |last2=Fox |first3=Phil |last3=Mattingly |title=Trump again falsely blames the Democrats for his administration's family separations|publisher=CNN|date=June 16, 2018|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/15/politics/family-separation-democrats-trump/index.html |quote='The Democrats forced that law upon our nation,' Trump told reporters.}}</ref><ref name=Davis>{{cite news|author=Julie Hirschfeld Davis|title=Trump Again Falsely Blames Democrats for His Separation Tactic|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 16, 2018|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/16/us/politics/trump-democrats-separation-policy.html |quote='I hate the children being taken away', Mr. Trump told reporters on Friday in front of the White House during a 45-minute impromptu question-and-answer session on a wide range of topics. 'The Democrats have to change their law — that's their law.'}}</ref> The Trump administration's own "[[zero tolerance]]" policy announced in April 6, 2018, is responsible for spurring the separations.<ref name=WoodwardSpagat>{{cite news |last1=Woodward |first1=Calvin |last2=Spagat |first2=Elliot |title=Trump assails Dems for his own migrant policy |url=https://apnews.com/c597b0fafa194f9d8ab23238c9b7be86 |accessdate=June 17, 2018}}</ref> Trump also said he "certainly wouldn't sign the more moderate" immigration bill proposed by leaders of the House of Representatives with input from moderate Republicans and the White House.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lind |first1=Dara |title=Trump just said he "certainly wouldn't sign" an immigration bill his White House helped write |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/6/15/17467638/immigration-bill-trump-congress |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|date=June 15, 2018}}</ref>
On June 20, 2018, Trump announced that he would sign an executive order to end family separations, saying "We're going to keep families together but we still have to maintain toughness or our country will be overrun by people, by crime." He did so later the same day.<ref>{{cite news |first1=Scott |last1=Detrow |first2=Kelsey |last2=Snell |first3=Miles |last3=Parks |title=Trump Says He Will Sign Order To End Family Separations |publisher=NPR |date=June 16, 2018|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/06/20/621798823/speaker-ryan-plans-immigration-votes-amid-doubts-that-bills-can-pass}}</ref>
On June 22, 2018, the President sent a tweet recommending Republicans to wait until after the November midterm elections to pass immigration legislation.<ref>{{cite news |author=Veronica Stracqualursi|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/22/politics/trump-immigration-midterms/index.html|title=Trump says GOP should 'stop wasting their time on immigration' until after midterms|publisher=CNN|date=June 22, 2018|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref> Trump continued to attempt to rally support, by hosting "Angel Families" at the White House on June 23; families whose loved ones had been killed by illegal immigrants. At the rally he pointed out that these families were "American citizens permanently separated from their loved ones".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-44580964|title=Trump hosts victims of illegal migrants|date=June 23, 2018|publisher=BBC News|access-date=June 24, 2018}}</ref> A fact check of Trump's statement noted that illegal immigrants are 25% less likely than native-born Americans, to commit homicide, and are 11.5% less likely to commit [[sexual assault]] than native-born Americans.<ref name="autogenerated5">{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/06/22/622540331/fact-check-trump-illegal-immigration-and-crime|title=FACT CHECK: Trump, Illegal Immigration And Crime |publisher=NPR |date=June 22, 2018 |accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref> The fact check also reported on a study which found that when more illegal immigrants move into a neighborhood, violent crime goes down.<ref name="autogenerated5"/>
==== Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen ==== During a June 18, 2018, White House press conference, [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Homeland Security]] Secretary [[Kirstjen Nielsen]] stated that during the first five months of fiscal 2018, there was a "314% increase in adults showing up with kids [posing as] a family unit. Those are traffickers, those are smugglers, that is MS-13, those are criminals, those are abusers." Using DHS data, analysis by ''The Washington Post'' found that such groups constituted 0.61% of "family units" apprehended at the border during that period.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2018/06/18/how-to-mislead-with-statistics-dhs-secretary-nielsen-edition/|title=Analysis – How to mislead with statistics, DHS Secretary Nielsen edition |last=Bump |first=Philip |date=June 18, 2018|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=June 19, 2018 |quote=A DHS representative provided The Washington Post with the hard numbers behind Nielsen's statistic. There were 46 cases of fraud — "individuals using minors to pose as fake family units" — in fiscal 2017, the period from October 2016 through September 2017. In the first five months of 2018, there were 191 cases. That is an increase of 315 percent.<br>Even given the increased number of alleged smugglers this fiscal year and the decreased number of family units, those smugglers, those traffickers, those MS-13 members make up only 0.61 percent of the total number of family units}}</ref>
In the same press conference she stated "We now care for them.... We have high standards. We give them meals. We give them education. We give them medical care. There's videos, there's TVs...." and stated when asked about family separation that a "vast majority" of children held are unaccompanied minors.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/06/18/dhs-head-nielsen-says-immigration-crisis-is-not-new-product-legislative-loopholes.html |title=DHS head Nielsen says immigration crisis 'is not new,' calls on Congress to act |last=Chamberlain |first=Samuel |date=June 18, 2018 |publisher=Fox News |access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> On June 19, 2018, Nielsen was heckled by protesters shouting "Shame! Shame! ... If kids don't eat in peace, you don't eat in peace," as she ate in a Mexican restaurant.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/20/politics/kirstjen-nielsen-mexican-restaurant-protest/index.html |title=Kirstjen Nielsen jeered at by protesters while dining at Mexican restaurant |author=Madison Park |publisher=CNN |access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
==== Attorney General Jeff Sessions ==== Following Christian opposition to the policy, Sessions controversially defended it by citing the [[Romans 13|thirteenth chapter of the Epistle to the Romans]] in the [[New Testament]],<ref name="Zauzmer15">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2018/06/14/jeff-sessions-points-to-the-bible-in-defense-of-separating-immigrant-families/|title=Sessions cites Bible passage used to defend slavery in defense of separating immigrant families |last=Zauzmer |first=Julie|date=June 15, 2018|newspaper=The Washington Post|access-date=June 15, 2018|last2=McMillan|first2=Keith}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/06/romans-13/562916/|title=The Fight to Define Romans 13|last=Mullen|first=Lincoln|date=June 15, 2018|work=The Atlantic}}</ref> saying "I would cite you to the [[Apostle Paul]] and his clear and wise command in Romans 13, to obey the laws of the government because God has ordained them for the purpose of order."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/jeff-sessions-immigration-children-parents-separated-bible-romans-13-a8405856.html|title=Opinion: This is what the Bible's Romans 13 actually says about asylum and what Jeff Sessions omitted|work=The Independent|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref> Several commentators have noted that before the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], Romans 13 was traditionally used by advocates of [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] to justify it, and to attack [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionists]].<ref name=Zauzmer14>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2018/06/14/jeff-sessions-points-to-the-bible-in-defense-of-separating-immigrant-families/|title=Jeff Sessions cites Romans 13, a Bible passage used to defend slavery, in defense of family separations|last=Zauzmer|first=Julie|date=June 14, 2018|newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
On June 19, Sessions disputed claims by former CIA Director [[Michael Hayden (general)|Michael Hayden]] that the separation of the immigrant families at the border was similar to what happened at the [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]] [[concentration camp]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-44538110|title=Sessions denies migrant centres Nazi-like|date=June 19, 2018|publisher=BBC News|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref> During the interview he said that the comparisons were inaccurate as the Nazis "were keeping the Jews from leaving the country". In the same interview, he stated that if the parents are deported the children return with them, but if the parents claim asylum and stay the children are put into the custody of Department of Health and Human Services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/19/politics/jeff-sessions-immigration-border-separation/index.html|title=Sessions: Migrant children facilities not like Nazi Germany because 'they were keeping the Jews from leaving'|author=Veronica Stracqualursi|publisher=CNN|access-date=June 19, 2018}}</ref>
== Executive Order to suspend new separations and detain families == {{see also|List of executive actions by Donald Trump#2018}} On June 20, 2018, President Trump signed Executive Order 13841,<ref name=AffordingRegister>{{Cite news|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/06/25/2018-13696/affording-congress-an-opportunity-to-address-family-separation|title=Affording Congress an Opportunity To Address Family Separation|date=June 25, 2018|work=Federal Register|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> titled "Affording Congress an Opportunity to Address Family Separation",<ref name=AffordingHouse>{{Cite news|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/affording-congress-opportunity-address-family-separation/|title=Affording Congress an Opportunity to Address Family Separation|publisher=The White House|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> that restricts family separation but maintains many of the key components of the Administration's immigration policy. The Order instructs the Department of Homeland Security to maintain custody of parents and children jointly, "to the extent permitted by law and subject to the availability of appropriations".<ref name=WagnerMiroff>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/gop-leaders-voice-hope-that-bill-addressing-family-separations-will-pass-thursday/2018/06/20/cc79db9a-7480-11e8-b4b7-308400242c2e_story.html|title=Trump reverses course, signs order ending his policy of separating families at the border |last=Wagner |first=John |last2=Miroff |first2=Nick |date=June 20, 2018 |work=The Washington Post|access-date=June 20, 2018|last3=DeBonis|first3=Mike}}</ref> It also instructs the Justice Department to attempt to overturn the Flores Agreement, which limited the time for holding children and families with children to 20 days, allowing children to be [[Indefinite detention without trial|detained indefinitely]].<ref name=WagnerMiroff /> The order directs other agencies, including the Pentagon to create or procure spaces to house the family units, however the family unit will not be maintained if there is fear for the child's welfare.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/20/politics/trump-separation-action-immigration/index.html|title=Trump reverses course, signs order to keep families together|authors=Stephen Collinson, Sarah Westwood, Laura Jarrett and Tal Kopan|publisher=CNN|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
At the signing ceremony, Trump said, "We're going to have strong, very strong borders but we are going to keep the families together. I didn't like the sight or the feeling of families being separated."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/20/us/politics/trump-immigration-children-executive-order.html|title=Trump Retreats on Separating Families, Signing Order to Detain Them Together|last=Haberman|first=Maggie|date=June 20, 2018|work=The New York Times |last2=Shear |first2=Michael |access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> Trump emphasised that families would be kept together, yet zero tolerance would continue.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/politics/live-news/immigration-border-children-separation/h_736e0a322bf643474f887e8077d1454b|title=JUST IN: President Trump signs executive order on keeping families together|publisher=CNN |date=June 20, 2018|access-date=July 8, 2018}} "We are keeping families together. This will solve that problem. At the same time, we are keeping a very powerful border and it continues to be a zero tolerance. We have zero tolerance for people that enter our country illegally."</ref>
At least two senior aides said that Republican Party leadership had no formal notice from the White House that there was planned executive action.<ref name=CBSinteractive>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-signs-executive-order-on-family-separation-live-stream/|title=Trump signs executive order on family separation but says "zero tolerance" to stay|access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref> The Chief Federal Public Defender in Southern Texas, Marjorie Meyers said that her official initially received no information about how the order would play out.<ref name=HeathGarciaMortizArceCollinsShesgreenJohnson>{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/06/21/family-separation-what-trump-order-has-changed-immigrant-children/720372002/ |title=What's changed after Trump's immigration order: For families, for the military and for Congress|work=USA Today|date= June 21, 2018 |author=Brad Heath in McLean, Va.; Julie Garcia and John C. Moritz in Brownsville, Texas; Javier Arce in Phoenix; and Eliza Collins, Deirdre Shesgreen and Kevin Johnson in Washington}}</ref>
=== Continued detention of separated children === Following the issue of the Executive Order, the Department of Health and Human Services stated that the status of children already detained would not be affected by the Executive Order, and that they would not be immediately reunited with their families.<ref name=ShearNYT2018-06-20>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/20/us/politics/trump-immigration-children-executive-order.html|title=Trump Retreats on Separating Families, but Thousands May Remain Apart|last=Shear|first=Michael D.|date=June 20, 2018|work=The New York Times |last2=Goodnough |first2=Abby |last3=Haberman |first3=Maggie |access-date=June 21, 2018}}</ref> However, it was later reported that the statement by Kenneth Wolfe, a spokesman for the [[Administration for Children and Families]], that "there will be no grandfathering of existing cases" was based on incorrect information and no decision had been made.<ref name=HeathGarciaMortizArceCollinsShesgreenJohnson/>
A fact sheet on "Zero-Tolerance Prosecution and Family Reunification" that was released by the Department of Health and Human Services, stated that a parent may request that their child be deported with them. However, the agency said that in the past many parents had elected to be deported without their children.<ref name=UT24/>
On June 26, Secretary of Health and Human Services [[Alex Azar]] testified that 2,047 children continued to be held in HHS-contracted facilities.<ref name=Itkowitz/> He said that only parents who are deported or who are granted entry to the United States could be reunited with their children.<ref name=Itkowitz/> He further testified that the Department would only reunite children with their detained parents if Congress passed legislation lifting the 20-day limit on family detention required under the Flores settlement.<ref name=Itkowitz/> Azar also implied that around 250 children formerly in HHS custody had been reunited with family members in the United States, rather with those they had accompanied across the border.<ref name=Itkowitz/>
On June 28, a bill was passed at the initiative of [[Tom Udall|Senator Tom Udall]] that requires HHS to make information about migrant children in its care publicly available. This obligation includes weekly public updates on its website of the number of children who have been reunited with separated family members, as well as monthly publication of the information on migrant children that the HHS makes available to the [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations]] under the Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education (Labor-HHS) Appropriations Bill.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tomudall.senate.gov/news/press-releases/udall-amendment-requires-hhs-transparency-on-family-separation|title=Udall Amendment Requires HHS Transparency on Family Separation|publisher=Senator Tom Udall |date=June 28, 2017|access-date=June 30, 2018}}</ref>
=== Transition and continued separation === On June 22, the office of U.S. Attorney [[John Bash]] stated that the zero tolerance policy was still in effect. He spoke of "a necessary transition" during which those who were charged would no longer be transferred to the custody of US Marshals but would stay in the custody of the DHS together with their children. The office confirmed that several cases that had been pending when the executive order had been issued were dismissed as part of that transition.<ref>{{cite news |author=Matthew Nussbaum, Eliana Johnson, Nancy Cook|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/21/trump-administration-family-separations-conflicting-statements-662618|title=Trump's herky-jerky immigration moves sow confusion|newspaper=Politico |date=June 22, 2018|access-date=June 22, 2018}}</ref>
Parents and children crossing the border illegally were intended to have the same [[Alien registration number|A-file number]] given to them by immigration officials. Family reunification was complicated by the fact that in many cases families were separated before an A-file number was given, resulting in parents and children receiving different numbers which makes it more difficult to reunite them afterwards.<ref>{{cite news |author=Ritu Prasad|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-44581240|title=Undocumented migrant families embark on chaotic reunion process|publisher=BBC|date=June 23, 2018|access-date=June 23, 2018}}</ref> Days after the formal end of the policy, authorities still were not able to tell the separated children how their parents were doing, or where their parents were.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4291434/donald-trump-migrant-family-separation-reunification/|title='It's heartbreaking': Advocates work to reunite migrant kids with parents amid U.S. separation crisis|publisher=Globalnews|date=June 22, 2018|access-date=June 24, 2018}}</ref>
DHS and HHS stated that they "have a process established to ensure that family members know the location of their children and have regular communication after separation to ensure that those adults who are subject to removal are reunited with their children for the purposes of removal", and that ICE had "implemented an identification mechanism to ensure on-going tracking of linked family members throughout the detention and removal process".<ref name=PAFR/> The [[Port Isabel Detention Center|Port Isabel Service Processing Center]] was intended to become the primary family reunification and removal center for adults who were in the custody of the ICE.<ref name=PAFR>{{cite web|url=https://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2018/06/23/zero-tolerance-prosecution-and-family-reunification.html|title=Zero-Tolerance Prosecution and Family Reunification|publisher=HHS|date=June 23, 2018|access-date=June 24, 2018}}</ref> The document did not set out any timeline for reuniting the remaining children that had been separated from their families due to the policy.
The DHS and HHS documents stated that adults who had been processed for removal would have the choice of whether or not their child would accompany them.<ref name=FactSheet/> CNN reported that adult detainees were being offered the opportunity to see their children if they agreed to sign voluntary departure orders, waiving their right to go before a judge. Immigration advocates criticized the policy; Attorney Efrén Olivares of the Texas Civil Rights Project said, "We have no reason to believe that (voluntary deportation) is the fastest way for parents to be reunited with their children. Putting them in that position is not a voluntary (deportation); it's being obtained under [[Duress in American law|duress]]."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/24/politics/family-reunification-deportation-orders/index.html|title=Separated parents given option for voluntary deportation amid child reunification|author=Tal Kopan, Eli Watkins, Sonia Moghe|publisher=CNN|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref>
[[United States Department of Health and Human Services|HHS]] also stated that ICE officials had posted notices in all of its facilities advising detained parents who were trying to find or communicate with their children to call a hotline, staffed from 8 AM to 8 PM, Monday through Friday. Further according to [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]], the parents can also contact the [[Office of Refugee Resettlement|Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR)]] National Call Center, to determine if the child is in custody of HHS.<ref name=UT24>{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/06/24/trump-administration-says-knows-location-all-border-children/728800002/ |title=Trump administration says it knows the location of all border children|work=USA Today|date=June 24, 2018 }}</ref> ORR is able to locate every child within seconds, but has limited access to information about whether a child arrived at the border with an adult.<ref name="politico-2018-07-04">{{Cite news|first1=Ted|last1=Hesson|first2=Dan|last2=Diamond|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/02/separated-families-border-children-reunite-664674|title=As deadline looms, Trump officials struggle to reunite migrant families|newspaper=Politico|date=July 2, 2018|access-date=July 4, 2018}}</ref>
=== Preparations for new detention facilities === The June 20 Executive Order instructs that, "The Secretary of Defense shall take all legally available measures to provide to the Secretary, upon request, any existing facilities available for the housing and care of alien families, and shall construct such facilities if necessary and consistent with law."<ref name=AffordingHouse/> On June 21, the Department of Health and Human Services requested facilities to house migrant children. Pentagon spokesmen and a memorandum sent to Congress confirmed that the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] was preparing facilities at four military bases in Texas and Arkansas—Fort Bliss, [[Dyess Air Force Base]], [[Goodfellow Air Force Base]], and [[Little Rock Air Force Base]]—to house 20,000 "[[Unaccompanied Alien Children|unaccompanied alien children]]".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/21/us/politics/trump-immigration-border-family-separation.html|title=U.S. Prepares to House Up to 20,000 Migrants on Military Bases|last=Shear|first=Michael|date=June 21, 2018|work=The New York Times |last2=Cooper|first2=Helene|last3=Benner|first3=Kate |access-date=June 24, 2018}}</ref> On June 25, the Associated Press reported that Fort Bliss and Goodfellow Air Force Base had been chosen, and that one will house unaccompanied migrant children, while the other will house migrant families.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.military.com/daily-news/2018/06/25/migrant-detainees-be-housed-2-texas-military-bases.html|title=Migrant Detainees to Be Housed at 2 Texas Military Bases|date=June 25, 2018|publisher=Military.com|access-date=June 25, 2018}}</ref>
On June 22, 2018, [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' Magazine]] reported the contents of an internal Navy planning memorandum that proposed constructing "tent cities" to house migrants in "temporary and austere" facilities at Navy Outlying Field Wolf in Orange Beach, Alabama, Navy Outlying Field Silverhill, and two abandoned airfields near Mobile, Alabama. The memorandum also proposes that up to 47,000 people could be house at both the former [[Concord Naval Weapons Station]] in northern California and [[Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton|Camp Pendleton]] in southern California. These would be built by the [[United States Navy|Navy]] and operated by the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|Department of Health and Human Services]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/5319334/navy-detainment-centers-zerol-tolerance-immigration-family-separation-policy/|title=Exclusive: Navy Document Shows Plan to Erect 'Austere' Tent Cities for Immigrants|last=Elliott|first=Philip|last2=Hennigan|first2=W.J.|date=June 22, 2018|website=Time|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 24, 2018}}</ref>
=== Suspension of detentions for new cases === On June 21, 2018, ''The Washington Post'' reported that Customs and Border Protection had suspended criminal referrals for parents arriving across the border with their children. At the time, Justice Department officials said the zero tolerance policy remained in force and they would continue to process all adults for illegal entry.<ref name=Miroff>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-will-stop-prosecuting-parents-who-cross-the-border-illegally-with-children-official-says/2018/06/21/4902b194-7564-11e8-805c-4b67019fcfe4_story.html|title=Reversal on migrant families deepens confusion over Trump's immigration order |last=Miroff |first=Nick |date=June 21, 2018|work=The Washington Post |last2=Lamothe|first2=Dan|last3=Kim|first3=Seung Min }}</ref>
On June 25, U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner [[Kevin McAleenan]] announced a temporary suspension of detaining migrant adults who traveled with children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/25/us/politics/border-officials-suspend-handing-over-migrant-families-to-prosecutors.html|title=Border Officials Suspend Handing Over Migrant Families to Prosecutors|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="bbc-2018-06-26">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-44609876|title=US relaxes 'zero tolerance' on migrants|date=June 26, 2018|publisher=BBC News|access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref> In this context, White House press secretary Sarah Sanders explained that the government was "out of resources" and could not hold all the undocumented families coming across the US-Mexico border.<ref name="bbc-2018-06-26" />
=== Difficulties of the reunification process === [[File:Separated Parent's Removal Form.pdf|thumb|right|"Separated Parent's Removal Form" gives parent being deported the option of leaving their child behind.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Valencia |first1=Nick |last2=Kopan |first2=Tal |title=The options parents facing deportation have after they've been separated from their kids |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/03/politics/deportation-parents-separated-from-kids/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=July 3, 2018}}</ref>]] Three agencies were involved in processing immigrant families: Customs and Border Patrol, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and the Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Refugee Resettlement. These agencies did not have a shared database for tracking migrant families, complied inaccurate summary data on the separation program, failed to consistently connect family members with their detained loved ones, and provided inaccurate information to family members, according to the DHS Inspector General's report.<ref name=":8">{{Cite conference|last=U.S. Department of Homeland Security. Office of the Inspector General.|first=|date=2018-09-27|title=Special Review - Initial Observations Regarding Family Separation Issues Under the Zero Tolerance Policy|url=|conference=|location=Washington, DC|volume=|pages=9-15|via=}}</ref> On June 23, DHS falsely claimed it and HHS had a "central database" for tracking migrants; the Department's Inspector General "found no evidence that such a database exists."<ref name=":8" />
In early July, ORR staff were still missing instructions on how to proceed in order to reunite the separated children with their parents. The deadline for reuniting children under five years of age with their parents was July 10, for all others it was July 26. After the court order, the HHS manually reviewed all case files of the approximately 11,800 children in their custody to determine whether HHS missed any who had been separated from adults at the border. Matters were further complicated by the fact that parents may have been in different situations: released, still detained, or deported.<ref name="politico-2018-07-04" /><ref name="judge-rejects-blanket-delay-2018-07-06">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/07/06/us/ap-us-immigration-separating-families.html|title=Judge rejects blanket delay to reunite children at border|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 6, 2018|accessdate=July 7, 2018}}</ref>
The usual procedure for the release of a child to a sponsor involves a background check. Sponsors must submit documentation proof that they are legitimate relatives and financially capable. They also have to pay for travel costs, in some cases thousands of US dollars for air fares.<ref>{{Cite news|first1=Miriam|last1=Jordan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/01/us/migrant-children-families.html|title=Sponsors of Migrant Children Face Steep Transport Fees and Red Tape|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 1, 2018|access-date=July 4, 2018}}</ref> Since June 2018, the procedure also involves the [[fingerprint]]ing of every adult in a potential sponsor's household. The procedure is said to be intended to avoid the risk of releasing children to unauthorized persons or child traffickers. Representatives of plaintiffs argue that the usual procedure is too slow for the release of a child to their parent.<ref name="politico-2018-07-04"/>
CNN reported that [[DNA testing]] was performed to expedite parental verification and ensure reunification with verified parents, without details being reported as to whether consent has been asked. Human rights advocates have criticized that migrant children, some as young as two months old, cannot give their consent to DNA testing.<ref>{{cite news |author=Sonia Moghe, Nicole Chavez|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/07/05/politics/dna-testing-migrant-family-separation/index.html|title=DNA testing being done on separated migrant children and parents, official says|publisher=CNN|date=July 5, 2018|access-date=July 5, 2018}}</ref> Medical experts have recommended to use DNA testing only as a last resort. Thomas H. Murray, president emeritus of [[The Hastings Center]], emphasizes the danger to social ties in the family given that "the risk [[Non-paternity event#Definitions and uses|misattributed fatherhood]], and even motherhood, is more common than most people realize".<ref>{{cite news |author=Ricardo Alonso-Zaldivar, Elliott Spagat|url=http://time.com/5335372/separated-migrant-families-dna-testing/|title=Medical Experts Say DNA Testing to Reunite Separated Migrant Families Should be a Last Resort|publisher=Time|date=July 11, 2018|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
==== Deadline ==== Azar declared on July 5 that the government would meet the July 10 deadline for uniting children under five years of age with their parents, and confirmed that DNA testing was being used to speed up matching parents and children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2018-07-05/the-latest-government-will-meet-court-deadlines#close-modal|title=The Latest: Government Will Meet Court Deadlines|publisher=US News & World Report |date=July 5, 2018|access-date=July 5, 2018}}</ref> He also stated that the Department of Homeland Security was relocating parents of children under 5 years old to detention facilities close to their children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/u-moving-detained-migrants-sites-closer-children-hhs-170244140.html|title=U.S. moving some detained migrants to sites closer to their children - HHS secretary|date=July 5, 2018|access-date=July 5, 2018}}</ref> In advance of the deadline of July 26 that had been set for reunification of minors of five years of age or older, the administration stated on July 16 that it had completed reunifying "all eligible children under five", and that families with older children were being reunited on a rolling basis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mysanantonio.com/news/texas/article/The-Latest-Judge-halts-deportations-of-reunited-13078952.php|title=The Latest: Texas shelter: US flying kids for reunifications|publisher=My San Antonio |date=July 16, 2018|access-date=July 22, 2018}}</ref> On July 25, ACLU filed a submission setting out that some of the parents had been misled to relinquish their right to reunite with their children.<ref>{{cite news |author=Aamna Mohdin|url=https://qz.com/1341985/the-aclu-claims-immigrant-parents-in-the-us-didnt-understand-contracts-that-waived-their-right-to-be-reunited-with-their-children/|title=Read: Immigrant parents describe signing reunification waivers they didn't understand|publisher=qz.com|date=July 27, 2018|access-date=July 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>[https://www.aclu.org/legal-document/ms-l-v-ice-plaintiffs-reply-support-motion-stay-removal ACLU filing of July 25, 2018].</ref>
On July 26, the Trump administration said that 1,442 children had been reunited with their parents while 711 remained in government shelters because their cases are still under review, their parents have [[criminal record]]s, or their parents are no longer in the United States. Officials stated that 431 parents of those children had already been deported without their children. Officials said they will work with the court to return the remaining children, including the children whose parents have been deported.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/> The most recent data, current as of August 20, shows that 528 of the children — about a fifth — have still not been reunited with their parents.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Trump administration’s legacy of orphans |url=https://wapo.st/2PH2h2m?tid=ss_mail&utm_term=.0711d879bb5d |accessdate=8 September 2018 |work=The Washington Post |date=26 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
=== Second chance === In September 2018, the Department of Justice changed their handling of asylum claims of asylum seekers who had undergone family separation. The change, which is said to give about 1,000 persons a second chance to claim asylum, is the result of a negotiation covering three lawsuits that had been filed against the government over the family-separation policy.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dara Lind|url=https://www.vox.com/2018/9/13/17853770/children-separated-news-update-parents-trump|title=As many as 1,000 parents separated from their children are getting a second chance to stay in the US|publisher=Vox|date=September 13, 2018|accessdate=September 20, 2018}}</ref>

[[Store Urevatn]] |outflow = River [[Otra]] |catchment = |basin_countries = [[Norway]] |date-built = |date-flooded = |length = {{convert|12.9|km}} |width = {{convert|1.4|km}} |area = {{convert|14.42|km2|abbr=on}} |depth = |max-depth = |volume = |residence_time = |shore = {{convert|29.76|km}} |elevation = {{convert|840|m}} |frozen = |islands = |cities = |reference = [[Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate|NVE]] }} '''Vatndalsvatnet''' or '''Vatnedalsvatnet''' is a [[lake]] in the municipality of [[Bykle]] in [[Aust-Agder]] county, [[Norway]]. The {{convert|14.42|km2|adj=on}} lake lies about {{convert|3|km}} west of the village of [[Berdalen]] and the river [[Otra]]. The nearby lakes [[Ormsavatnet]] and [[Store Urevatn]] flow into the lake through [[dam]]s and [[canal]]s. The lake Vatndalsvatnet also has a dam on it and the water flows out of the lake from the dam into the [[Otra]] river. The lake is located in the central part of Bykle, about halfway between the villages of [[Hovden, Aust-Agder|Hovden]] and [[Bykle (village)|Bykle]]. The mountains [[Snjoheinuten]] and [[Kvervetjønnuten]] both lie on the south side of the lake.{{cite web|url=http://www.yr.no/place/Norway/Aust-Agder/Bykle/Vatndalsvatnet/|title=Vatndalsvatnet|publisher=yr.no|language=Norwegian |accessdate=2010-05-16}} ==See also== *[[List of lakes in Aust-Agder]] *[[List of lakes in Norway]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{AustAgder-geo-stub}} {{Lakes in Norway}} [[Category:Lakes of Aust-Agder]] [[Category:Bykle]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Norway]]

'''Water privatization in Guayaquil''' began with the decision taken in 1995 to privatize drinking water supply and sewerage in [[Guayaquil]], the largest city and economic capital of [[Ecuador]], through a concession contract. In preparation for privatization, the previously separate water and sewer utilities were merged into a single utility in 1996. The new utility began a modernization process and began to improve its performance. In parallel, the international bidding for the concession was prepared by [[Banque Paribas]] as the international advisor and was supported by the [[Inter-American Development Bank]]. The latter made a loan that was signed in October 1997 conditional upon the decision to award a concession. The 30-year concession agreement between the city government and the private company Interagua was signed in 2001. The contract was "poor-friendly", requiring the private company to keep tariffs constant for the first five years and to connect new users in poor areas "at no cost".<ref name=Faro>{{cite web|last=Grupo Faro - Fundación para el Avance de las Reformas y las Oportunidades|title=Stay Public or Go Private? A comparative analysis of water services between Quito and Guayaquil|url=http://www.iadb.org/res/laresnetwork/files/pr264finaldraft.pdf|accessdate=30 June 2012|pages=6–9, 62–65|date=August 2006}}</ref> At the same time, the former municipal water and sewer utility ECAPAG became the regulatory agency for the new private utility. Interagua is a consortium led by the Spanish company Proactiva Medio Ambiente,<ref name="FP Guayaquil"/> which in turn is supported by the Spanish construction firm [[Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas|FCC]] and the French water company [[Veolia Environnement]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Proactive Medio Ambiente|title=Líderes en servicios medioambientales|url=http://www.proactiva.es/es/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17&Itemid=17|accessdate=30 June 2012}}</ref> In 2012 the regulator ECAPAG was transformed into the Municipal Public Drinking Water and Sanitation Company of Guayaquil in what may be a first step towards the municipalization of the concession.
==Financing and investments== The investments undertaken by the concessionaire are financed through retained earnings, the municipality and the State Bank of Ecuador. The government funds are deposited into a trust fund that the concessionnaire can only access under certain conditions. For the 2011-2016 period investments of US$ 380 million are expected to be financed by the concessionnaire (US$ 107.5 million), the municipality and the State Bank of Ecuador (US$ 150 million)<ref>{{cite web|title=Water: A success story|work=Guayaquil. The Power of Partnership. Interview with José Luis Santoas García, General Manager, ECAPAG|publisher=Foreign Policy, Special Advertisement Supplement|date=July–August 2012}}</ref> as well as the national government and the proceedings of a tax called Special Improvement Contributions (Contribucion Especial de Mejoriamiento, CEM).
==Impact== Before the concession, 50% of the city had only 10 hours service per day.<ref name=ECAPAG/> In parts of the city water was supplied only 2 to 4 hours per day, often at low pressure.<ref name="FP Guayaquil">{{cite web|title=Water: A success story|work=Guayaquil. The Power of Partnership.|publisher=Foreign Policy, Special Advertisement Supplement|date=July–August 2012}}</ref> Commercial and physical losses in water distribution, technically called [[non-revenue water]], stood at a staggering 79 percent. Only 46 percent of water bills were actually collected. And only 26 percent of all connections were metered.<ref name="El Comercio">{{cite web|last=El Comercio|title=Guayaquil: El agua va a Concesion|url=http://www.explored.com.ec/noticias-ecuador/guayaquil-el-agua-va-a-concesion-1069.html|accessdate=30 June 2012|date=15 July 1998}}</ref>
During its first five years the company brought 24 hours service to all the city and served an additional 55,000 families, mostly low income in the southern part of the city.<ref name=ECAPAG>ECAPAG:[http://www.ecapag.gov.ec/SoloPortalECAPAG/default.asp?idl=148 La Concesión - Primeros 5 años]</ref> Access to water supply increased from 64 percent in 2000 to 72 percent in 2003, and access to sewerage has grown from 46 percent to 55 percent during the same period.<ref name=IDB/> According to an article written by Interagua for public relations all the "formally developed areas" of the city had access to piped water at "reasonable pressure" in 2012.<ref name="FP Guayaquil"/> However, according to Interagua's own annual report 2009-2010, only an estimated 82 percent of the population (almost 2 million out of a population of 2.43 million) had access to piped water and 67 percent had access to sewerage in July 2010.<ref>{{cite web|last=Interagua|title=Informe Anual 2009 - 2010|url=http://www.interagua.com.ec/transparencia/archivos/informes/informe2009-2010.pdf|accessdate=30 June 2012|pages=1 and 33}}</ref> In 10 years access to piped water supply thus increased from 64 to 82 percent. Customers who gained access to piped water supply were able to consume twice as much water while paying one fifth of what they paid before, when they had bought it from vendors distributing it in tankers. Tankers charged US$ 3.50 per cubic meter, while Interagua charges only 34 cents per cubic meter for the first 15 cubic meters per month.<ref name=IDB>Paul Constance, IDB America:[http://www.iadb.org/idbamerica/index.cfm?thisid=2501 A fair price - In Guayaquil, Ecuador, a privatized water service bets that poor consumers will like metered water], November 2003</ref>
The concessionaire also increased billing efficiency - the share of bills issued that are paid - to about 75 percent by 2003. The number of staff was reduced by 43 percent between 2001 and 2003. This brought the number of staff per 1,000 connections down to less than 3, a level that is consistent with international good practice for an efficient utility.<ref>{{cite web|last=Philippe Marin|title=Public-Private Partnerships for Urban Water Utilities. A Review of Experiences in Developing Countries.|url=http://water.worldbank.org/publications/public-private-partnerships-urban-water-utilities-review-experiences-developing-countri|publisher=World Bank|accessdate=30 June 2012|pages=91, 97–98|year=2009}}</ref>
Some of the remaining challenges are fluctuating water pressure and high levels of [[non-revenue water]], consisting of both physical and commercial water losses. This is shown by the reports of the independent technical auditor who reviews annually the performance of Interagua. While the report confirmed that in 2010 at least 95 percent of all customers received water at a pressure above the minimum pressure, defined as 5 meters of water column (0.5 bar) in the center of the city and 8 meters of water column (0.8 bar) in the North of the city, the report contained no data about pressure variations and maximal pressure.<ref>{{cite web|last=JVP Consultores S.A., Auditor Técnico|title=Certificación del Informe Anual del Ano 10 de la Concesión|url=http://www.interagua.com.ec/transparencia/archivos/ResultadoAuditorias/Auditoriatecnica/Anio_2009-2010/Certif_InfoAnual10.pdf|accessdate=30 June 2012|location=Buenos Aires|pages=38|date=18 April 2012}}</ref> Interagua wants to achieve constant pressure throughout its service area by 2015 or 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Water: A success story|work=Guayaquil. The Power of Partnership. Interview with Oscar García, Acting General Manager, Interagua|publisher=Foreign Policy, Special Advertisement Supplement|date=July–August 2012}}</ref> In 2010 the level of non-revenue water was 62 percent.<ref>{{cite web|last=JVP Consultores S.A., Auditor Técnico|title=Certificación del Informe Anual del Ano 10 de la Concesión|url=http://www.interagua.com.ec/transparencia/archivos/ResultadoAuditorias/Auditoriatecnica/Anio_2009-2010/Certif_InfoAnual10.pdf|accessdate=30 June 2012|location=Buenos Aires|pages=32|date=18 April 2012}}</ref> This level is much higher than the average in Colombia (49 percent) or in Peru (44 percent).
There have been complaints of poor water quality in marginal communities. Residents of Guasmo Sur complained of turbid, foul smelling water that is not fit for consumption and residents of Suburbio Oeste have struggled through both a hepatitis outbreak and periodic issues of decreased chlorine content/increased fecal content in the samples from their sector in 2004.<ref name=Faro/>
==Comparison with public water management in Quito== A 2006 study conducted for the Inter-American Development Bank came to the conclusion that compared to Quito, which is served by a publicly managed water utility, water quality was worse in Guayaquil, the poor had less access to piped water and water tariffs were higher. In terms of trends, the study concluded that between 1995 and 2005 "poor homes decreased their likelihood of having access to water in Guayaquil relative to Quito".<ref name=Faro/>
==External links== * [http://www.interagua.com.ec/ Interagua (Concessionaire)] * [http://www.ecapag.gob.ec/ ECAPAG - Organismo de Control y Regulación de la Concesión (Regulator)]
==References== <references/>

[[File:Dried reindeer meat.jpg|thumb|250px|Dried reindeer meat]]
Traditional '''Yamal cuisine''' is an important part of national culture of [[Nenets people|Nenets]], [[Khanty people|Khanty]] and [[Komi peoples|Komi]]. [[Yamal Peninsula|Yamal]] is a [[hunting]] and [[fishing]] land so many dishes include meat, [[fowl]] and [[fish]]. [[Berry|Berries]] and [[mushroom]]s are also abundant; this accounts for the wealth of "gifts of the forests" on the Yamal table. Nowadays, Yamal cuisine is renowned for diverse delicacies of [[Russian cuisine]]. Yamal hosts enjoy treating their guests with traditional Yamal cuisine and have hot tea which came to Yamal cuisine from Russia. Tea has become the national Yamal [[beverage]], drunk to warm and soothe. Yamal is in northern Russia with frigid winters, so its cuisine should be nourishing to give the people energy to survive during the long winter time. The essential component of Yamal cuisine is warm and hot dishes. Fresh [[fruit]]s and [[vegetable]]s are rarely used as they must be imported, as they are not grown in the [[tundra]]. The Yamal cuisine is associated with [[malosol]] and [[stroganina]]. Yamal cuisine has absorbed techniques from other regions. Yamal cuisine is based on [[reindeer]] meat and fish of the Yamal rivers, enriched with mushrooms and [[bread]].
The most known dishes of Yamal cuisine are: Fish Soup made from [[burbot]]), Malosol, Bread on the Selkup, Stroganina (Sliced Fish), Chopsy Shomoh, Warka, Sliced meat, Preserves of vendace, Kulebyaka ([[pie]] with fish), Aibat-nyarhul (raw fish).
== Uha (fish soup) == [[Fish soup]] mostly is served as the first course at dinner. It is the typical Yamal dish. Fish Soup is prepared from the fish heads in the cauldron. Fish is cut up and cut into pieces and immersed in cold water. When boiling, the [[cauldron]] is moved aside to slow fire and skimmed when necessary. It should be brewed to a bluish-gray color and served at once. Usually it is drunk with a mug.
== Malosol == Malosol comes from [[Muksun]]. The key secret to this dish is cutting the fish into very delicate slices very fast in order that the fish remains slightly frozen. It is prepared from just caught muksun. Fish are gutted and cleaned, and liberally sprinkled with salt then held for 3-4 hours.
== Bread of Selkup == "Bread is head for everything" is a saying of Russians and [[Selkup people|Selkup]]s. It symbolizes hospitality of the house. Bread of Selkup is mentioned from the 8th-9th centuries. The bread is baked not in an oven as Russians do although the initial stages are the same. [[Flour]] is mixed with water and [[salt]]. Soda is used instead of [[yeast]] to raise the dough and it is baked in very hot sand on the fire.
== Hot smoked fish == {{Seealso|List of smoked foods}} Yamal cuisine has four principal types of fish dishes: “as it is”, boiled, baked and smoked. [[Smoked fish]] is very popular on the table nowadays. Hot smoked fish is prepared in the towns and villages, although it is not the national dish. Camp cooking uses an aluminum saucepan filled with smoldering sawdust, topped with a wire grid. A low heat is all that is needed to give the fish a golden hue, indicating doneness.
== Stroganina (sliced fish) == [[Stroganina]] have always been a pride of Yamal. It is a delicacy and a simple food which is prepared from frozen white [[salmon]]. Strips of skin are cut from the back and abdomen from tail to head. Vertical incisions are made in the flesh. The fish is placed head down on a hard surface and skinned. With sostragivaetsya, the fish is in thin slices or layers, depending on whether male or female fish are used.
== References == {{portal|Russia|Food}} * Dialectics of Yamal cuisine by Nikolai Dudnikov and Nikolai Samburov. S-pb. 2008 {{ISBN|978-5-901440-40-7}}
